text: I am glad this Coffee &amp; Toast is still around. This was my go to place for coffee in the morning when I was working in the area almost 10 years ago. Then, the menu was smaller and simpler with just the usual toast, soft boiled eggs and coffee or tea. Now you have other typical Singaporean food like laksa, mee siam and mee rebus besides toast. <br><br>My favorite toast was the peanut butter and honey and I have yet to find this combination at the other coffee toast joints. The coffee is strong but not too acidic bitter strong. <br><br>My other favorite set would be the otah bun with soft boiled eggs and kopi. I also like how you can choose to have your kaya butter on either soft buns or the thin crispy toast. <br><br>This is a good alternative to the ever crowded Ya Kun or Toastbox. Cheaper too, I think.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=hRMpQlJQDObCpNSJ1qd_fA', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/KBdaO8VXLPe1UqSkzRUNgA/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/KBdaO8VXLPe1UqSkzRUNgA/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/KBdaO8VXLPe1UqSkzRUNgA/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/KBdaO8VXLPe1UqSkzRUNgA/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/KBdaO8VXLPe1UqSkzRUNgA/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/KBdaO8VXLPe1UqSkzRUNgA/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Ricky S.', 'displayLocation': 'San Francisco, CA', 'altText': 'Ricky S.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=hRMpQlJQDObCpNSJ1qd_fA', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 77, 'photoCount': 537, 'reviewCount': 393, 'eliteYear': None}
text: I like Coffee &amp; Toast when I have a craving for a Singaporean breakfast. Their prices are reasonable at $4 for a Kopi (of your choice), 2 eggs, and kaya toast set.<br><br>Brought a colleague to this one for his first ever SG brekkie experience and he also enjoyed.<br><br>It took a few tries but I finally understand the appeal of the runny eggs with soy sauce and kaya toast topped off with some strong kopi. Delicious combo!

Bleary-eyed CBD workers form long queues in the morning to get their kopi fix. Local tea and coffee in the style of Ya Kun, Wang etc. but slightly cheaper than either place. <br><br>If I&#39;m desperate, I get a kopi - si or kopi - peng here .. these taste OK. The teh-o is very bitter and I&#39;m not a fan of the teh o peng either. <br><br>There are two counters, one for sit-in and one for take-aways. I&#39;ve only had their butter sugar and kaya toast, which I didn&#39;t like.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/DnV_R3y4eLS3Vy_I9aoqpQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/joe-and-dough-singapore-6?reviewid=fTKpFnYUc1F8JpyxjKLr6A&select=DnV_R3y4eLS3Vy_I9aoqpQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Joe & Dough - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: Joe &amp; Dough was currently having promotion from 31 March 2016 to 6 April 2016 to celebrate its 7 years. On 5 April 2016, the promotion of the day was $7 for a Drink and a piece of Cake. I visited the Square 2 outlet. There was still quite a number of choices of cakes for the promotion. As for the drinks, ice blended drinks were not included in the promotion.<br><br>Yuzu Surprise ($6.80)<br>It looked so delicate with a lightly browned meringue on top. Juicy tangy yuzu, crunchy chocolate, crunchy honeycomb filled the mouth.<br><br>Raspberry Latte ($5.50/ dine in)<br>It tasted quite sweet, maybe because I&#39;m having a sweet cake too. But the drink really warmed me up during a cold wet day.

Interior', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Interior'}]
text: It&#39;d be silly to say Novena doesn&#39;t have nice things, because it does. However, I feel Novena MRT is lacking in all-day dining options with free wifi, something that I&#39;m craving more and more.<br><br>I&#39;m excited that Joe &amp; Dough has swooped in and filled in this void. Located on the ground level of Square 2, this new outlet has space, fancy looking desserts, good coffee, and free wifi. It&#39;s one of the few places that are open for breakfast that isn&#39;t takeaway (Square 2 and Velocity mall is more concentrated with lunch/dinner establishments.)<br><br>The staff is friendly and I like the classic jazz soundtrack that they have playing in the background. They have colourful leather chairs throughout the cafe; however, they&#39;re paired with low coffee tables so it&#39;s not ideal if you need to be typing on a laptop. There&#39;s a big roundtable in the back, but it&#39;s really meant for a group of 6. Therefore, you&#39;ll find me sitting at the smaller coffee tables near the front!<br><br>Welcome to Novena, Joe &amp; Dough! Glad you&#39;re here!

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/zY1iZiSH9daAO3feGbdhEA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/joe-and-dough-singapore-6?reviewid=65Nh-1znSVLKSUnIBYofuw&select=zY1iZiSH9daAO3feGbdhEA', 'altText': 'Photo of Joe & Dough - Singapore, Singapore. Salt beef sandwich', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Salt beef sandwich'}]
text: Fancy a salt beef sandwich in Singapore? They&#39;re hard to come by... happily there is one at Joe and Dough. <br><br>I came specifically for the salt beef sandwich and so that&#39;s what we shall talk about.<br><br>It&#39;s a decent sandwich and will scratch your salt beef itch, hold you over till you get to London. Ha!<br><br>It&#39;s a few thin slices of salt beef with caramelised onions - nice taste of sweet onions. No mustard though. And I think a bit of cheese though mostly inconsequential and lost in the onions. So you&#39;re probably thinking: NO MUSTARD?! Yeah. Well we could have a lengthy conversation about this, you and me. <br><br>Taste-wise it&#39;s pretty decent. I wish there was more beef. Why are portions in Singapore always so kiam siap? The bread is a whole round roll of Rye bread. Nice crust, soft and tasty but a tad too much bread, I felt, accentuated by the tad too little beef. <br><br>And so all in all it left me pretty satisfied. I would certainly go back to scratch the salt beef sandwich itch but at the same time, dream of better days and better sandwiches...

text: Joe &amp; Dough is a little cafe near one of the entrances to the Square 2 shopping centre. It has a small range of sandwiches rolls and cakes, and offers some hot and cold drinks (teas and coffee etc). I had lunch there recently and the staff were very warm and friendly. Overall the cafe doesn&#39;t have a great range of food and the few sandwiches on offer didn&#39;t look very appealing. Unfortuently eating my tuna on rye sandwich didn&#39;t do anything to change my opinion.

Joe and Dough serves great coffee, desserts, and American-style sandwiches. The service is quick, the place is clean, and everything we had there was SO good. We went several times. I strayed and went across the hall to the Singaporean cuisine spot, but the line was long and service was terrible, so my advice is to stick with Joe and Dough if you&#39;re in the area!

text: Located on the street level of Velocity Mall right before large doors leading into Square 2. 2nd time eating at 2 different Wang Cafes and since I ordered the same thing both times, it seems consistent in quality and service. Nice spot to take a kopi break.

text: Amazingly balanced earl grey lavender cake, if you like these flavours. The chai cake was very strongly flavoured, but it would be interesting to get if you like chai. The maple cheese tart was not bad. <br><br>This place has totally overpriced drinks though. You might want to get a hot pot of tea to share.

text: An accidental find and absolutely a delightful place to be in! Service is great and the cakes we have tried so far are so amazing that I wish more people knew about this place. <br>We love it so much we were there 2 days in a roll just to enjoy the tea, cake and atmosphere.

text: This is an awesome find. Tried the strawberry shortcake (nice light texture, not overly sweet, fresh strawberries and cream) and Royce chocolate cake (my favourite- the bitterness of the royce chocolate is awesome). Ice mocha is perfect too.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=6SnKk4GcrXlaUpVXSVKDiw', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/8NDHTDQSzL3fNV4yp71l3Q/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/8NDHTDQSzL3fNV4yp71l3Q/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/8NDHTDQSzL3fNV4yp71l3Q/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/8NDHTDQSzL3fNV4yp71l3Q/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/8NDHTDQSzL3fNV4yp71l3Q/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/8NDHTDQSzL3fNV4yp71l3Q/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Colin W.', 'displayLocation': 'Holmdel, NJ', 'altText': 'Colin W.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=6SnKk4GcrXlaUpVXSVKDiw', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 0, 'photoCount': None, 'reviewCount': 6, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Ordered 2 cakes. Had a service issue. No service recovery, and no response to repeated emails addressed to sales team and orders team (in spite of incoming emails coming FROM these email addresses). I guess once the monetary transaction is complete, you&#39;re on your own. Subpar service. Take your business elsewhere. I&#39;m guessing the service team went on vacation because of COVID. Timeout SG wrote an article about the Best Cake Delivery Options in Singapore (Apr 24, 2020). Try those instead.
The white coffe was good but the chocolate ganache cake was dry and cold. I was underwhelmed. If you come here come here for coffee but not cake.

text: Excellent customer service.Recommendations on what&#39;s new really helps. I was hovering for probably a good few minutes at the seemingly endless choices.<br>Cake was dense,quoting the boyfriend,a value for money.<br><br>The mango topping was the best mango i had in a cake in my life! it wasnt glazed to death with syrup.

Original Ice Cheese Tart (cut to eat in)', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Original Ice Cheese Tart (cut to eat in)'}]
text: I understand that many come for their Japanese-French style cakes. But I came here to check it out but primarily to try their Ice Cheese Tart! Wasn&#39;t feeling a craving for cake, maybe another time. <br><br>Given it was my first time here I gave their original a try. It was good. A nice almond crust and good balance of not too too sweet cheese filling. It was perfect to eat there because they cut it into fours for you and it doesn&#39;t get warm too quickly, etc. Yum, they had so many other flavors. I&#39;ll definitely be back to try their Earl agree :) <br><br>Their other cake slices looked a little pricey and small. Their tea was cute in clear glass pots heated by a candle so it wouldn&#39;t get cold. Cool, but not worth $10 for a homemade blend in my opinion. Same with the iced coffee, $8 seems a bit steep for a normal size tall glass. <br><br>Anyways, the atmosphere was nice, loved how bright and simple the decor was. Overall I feel the patisserie is kind of pricey but it is a specialized niche so I guess it can get by. As I said I&#39;ll be back for their ice cheese tarts :) plus I found the Duxton Hill area is a nice area to walk around too. <br><br>Tip: come to hang out and share a pot of tea with some nice treats <br>Tip2: no wifi avail<br>Tip3: variety of treats to purchase from full cakes to packaged goodies too.

Strawberry Napoleon', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Strawberry Napoleon'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/wmoJGSeBaCXHcJ0afln2kA/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/flor-patisserie-singapore?reviewid=G3dVVxyQpIsM4BVECp5mKw&select=wmoJGSeBaCXHcJ0afln2kA', 'altText': 'Photo of Flor Patisserie - Singapore, Singapore. Tiramisu', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Tiramisu'}]
text: I will add my praises to the other Yelpers who have reviewed here and thank them for helping me find this gem.<br><br>I played it safe and ordered the tiramisu which somehow they managed to lift above expectations, the cream was heavenly and each mouthful melted into my mouth.<br><br>Claire tried the strawberry napoleon, which I scored a mouthful of which was also lovely; I only have a two days left but I hope to return and try more.

text: No idea what is all the hype about. Had better cakes in Singapore. Was really looking forward to trying their cakes and bringing my friend from overseas to let her try some really good desserts(based on all the reviews) but alas! Cakes were mediocre. It wasn&#39;t bad...but it was just normal and nothing spectacular given how it&#39;s priced. Our sweet tooth werent satisfied and decided to go to my usual place for cakes instead.

Wakakusayama at Flor Patisserie', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Wakakusayama at Flor Patisserie'}]
text: Flor Patisserie is a little bit of a trek for those who don&#39;t know the area well. Its closest MRT stations are Chinatown and Tanjong Pagar, but my friends and I unknowingly took a long walk from Outram Park Station with the help of a smartphone.<br><br>The patisserie is small - there&#39;s a capacity of six diners within the shop, with another three or so additional sets of tables and stools outside along the walkway. A few shelves affixed on the wall holds little bags of special cake-slices and cookies which are up for sale, such as walnut cookies, chocolate madeleines, butter cakes, coffee biscuits, sesame cookies, etc. Most of these have a covered bowl of sampling pieces by their side, which is great for curious tasters like myself.<br><br>The three-tiered display cabinet by the cashier was empty other than the top shelf, which was quite a shame, as options were limited, and it showed. My friend and I went for the mont blanc for $6.95. After unwrapping the surrounding foil, there lay a light yellow sponge cylinder topped with chestnut cream, pierced by chocolate curls and a flaky pastry shard. Unfortunately, the latter was soggy and papery, and I felt that the dessert should have done without it.<br><br>The taste of the entire cake was extremely subtle, a la Japanese baking style of Chef Yamashita. The first bite didn&#39;t speak much, but the light chestnut flavour came through with more bites, and a single sweet chestnut is later revealed under the carefully-piped cream. Both the texture of the sponge and cream was light and airy, very easy to eat. It was my first time trying a [i]mont blanc[/i], and I quite enjoyed it, but I must say that it was overpriced for its size.<br><br>I had a bit of my friend&#39;s Wakakusayama, [pause to catch breath] which is a green tea Swiss roll filled with red bean cream, topped with fruits and sweet chestnuts. ($7.30)<br><br>The flavour of green tea was strong in this cake. Rather heavy, almost bitter, not for those who usually stick to sweet treats. The red bean cream had a lot of authentic red bean taste, which is special to taste. <br><br>My friends and I decided to share an &#39;Ice Cheese Tart&#39; out of curiosity. Each tart costs $3.40, and has varieties of strawberry, green tea, maple, mango, chocolate &amp; orange, yuzu and caramel, which we ended up choosing.<br><br>The &#39;Ice Cheese Tart&#39; turned out to be pretty much a frozen mini-cheesecake stuck fast to a paper mould, with an almond biscuit base. It was pretty annoying trying to bite or cut through the rock-solid cheesecake, but we didn&#39;t have patience to wait for it to thaw either.<br><br>The taste of the cheese tart was striking, and absolutely great. There&#39;s a distinct saltiness in the cream cheese which really improves the flavour of it. I didn&#39;t notice any obvious caramel flavour, but I&#39;m guessing it was infused into the cream cheese somehow. I wouldn&#39;t mind going back to try the other flavours, especially maple, but I do wish they would sell these un-frozen!<br><br>Just when the three of us thought that we&#39;d had enough cake for the day, a tray of Strawberry Soufflé ($6.60) magically appeared on the only-occupied shelf in the display cabinet when it wasn&#39;t there before, threatening to become dessert for our dessert!<br><br>Gotta have it, we thought. It was okay height-wise, but was a narrow slice. Piled with blueberries and strawberries encased in clear jelly, the cake is made up of a thick middle layer of light, aerated cheesecake topped with chantilly cream and strawberry chunks, all sandwiched between light sponge cake, plus fine biscuit crumbs stuck to the side.<br><br>It was a very impressive cake, and I loved the hint of lemon in the cheesecake, which gave it a quiet, pleasant tang. Despite it being cheesecake, it was not too rich at all, because of the soufflé technique used to create an airy texture. My friends commented on sour strawberries, but the ones I ate seemed fine. This is a cake I&#39;d come back for, it&#39;s delicious.<br><br>Due to the long walk under the hot, late-afternoon sun, we each got iced tea to cool ourselves down and quench our thirst. My friends went for green tea, a peach tea, and for myself, a mango tea. ($4.50, except for the green tea which was slightly cheaper)<br><br>The teas were very pure - teabag, water, ice cubes, and no added sugar. I could barely taste mango in mine, but it was refreshing, nevertheless. The staff at Flor gladly lets you top up the water in your cup, so you can maximise the use of the teabag.<br><br>We each ended up spending about $15 per person, with all the drinks and shared cakes. Not somewhere one would frequent as a student, but a nice, quiet place to go for an occasional dessert-escapade, especially if you&#39;re into Japanese desserts.

text: decent-alright japanese-styled-french cakes at this tiny cafe in duxton hill. flor patisserie is pretty well-known for its light, japanese cream-type cakes, but I hadn&#39;t gotten to it previously on my dessert circuit precisely because of those characteristics: I like my cakes hefty and substantial, and these fluffy, creamy things do little for me.<br><br>but for its class, the desserts are good - certainly worth a visit if you&#39;re into this sort of thing. there&#39;s no way to get around this - this place is pretty much fantastic for women (and persons inclined toward the delicate and feminine). it&#39;s a small white-walled space with a large window that lets in plenty of light at brunchtime, and the counter is laid full with colorful, dainty little cakes with all sorts of fancy frosting and glazes.<br><br>we had five cakes from the selection on offer that day - mango (the unanimously-declared winner of the day), strawberry, yam, chocolate and blueberry - and whilst there was a mix of textures from millefeuille and the sponges, all the cakes felt the same.<br><br>everything&#39;s certainly gorgeous - but all a little too light and substantial. of course, this opinion speaks more of my preferences than the skill of the kitchen; if you&#39;re into this sort of thing, it does well enough (and you might also want to try its famous ex-chef&#39;s new venture: his eponymously-named chef yamashita).

Love the strawberry souffle and the berry berries cake. <br>the cake is light, the cream was good too and it didn&#39;t leave any after taste :)<br>Ice cheese tart was good, but the cakes are far better.

text: It&#39;s very subtle the tastes. To be honest by the look, nothing looks too impressive. I just think it&#39;s a food bloggers dream in taking pics but I think nothing special.

The Vert', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'The Vert'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/beSKcRh04w4kfV-XMzqnpQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/flor-patisserie-singapore?reviewid=ogkrv3uxW5hfZ6KYvXV8Hg&select=beSKcRh04w4kfV-XMzqnpQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Flor Patisserie - Singapore, Singapore. Chestnut mille feuille', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Chestnut mille feuille'}]
text: I was surprised to see how small the space is. Some tables and chairs to accommodate 6 and another 3 stools along a small bar counter. Outside the shop, there&#39;re dining space for another 8 perhaps? I reckon it&#39;s more of a bakery for cakes to go. But anyway we decided to camp there for a while to enjoy the cakes.  <br><br>The green tea cake is very light and this is very typical of Japanese cakes. I love the Japanese cheesecake with that cow logo on it. I can finish at least half a cake in a sitting (i swear it). It doesn&#39;t feel sinful at all. Every mouthful simply disappears into a fragrant mix that glides down your throat. It feels like a dream because you&#39;re not sure if you really did eat it at all. <br><br>The matcha is strong but not overpowering and the green tea sponge cake was also very airy and moist. I like the green tea jelly which sits on top of the cake. It adds an additional dimension to the creamy texture, kinda chewy but not much? Flor uses the Kyoto-uji matcha for the pristine flavor and aroma and it&#39;s a damn good choice.<br><br>The Waguri millefeuille was also very nice. Same quality to the sponge cake. I would reckon that their toufu chiffon cake would have the same texture. Z had it before and said that it&#39;s pretty good but pricey for a chiffon cake ($13.80 for 1 if i didn&#39;t remember wrongly). There&#39;s a nice mix of custard and cream with the puff pastry.<br><br>Typically, a mille-feuille would have 3 layers of pastry and 2 layers of creme but this only has 2 layers of pastry. I&#39;m not too picky about stuff like that. I personally thought this has a nice pastry to cream/cake ratio. Any more and i would feel like i&#39;m trying to sandpaper the insides of the throat.<br><br>Pastry was well done, has a nice bite to it and wasn&#39;t at all moist or flat from the creme. The chestnut paste goes down really easy. I&#39;ve tried several chestnut based desserts such as the Mont Blanc from Antoinette but they are kinda dense and dry as compared to Flor&#39;s. Z and i had a discussion about the chestnuts that were used to made these desserts and if they differ from those we typically see at the night markets. Think it&#39;s the same?<br><br>Anyhoo, the cakes didn&#39;t even take up much space in our tummies and we ordered their iced cheese tarts. They have quite a couple of flavors e.g. orange chocolate, caramel, green tea with yuzu and a couple of others. It has an almond cookie base and is filled with a lightly salted cream cheese filling (Flor&#39;s signature) and goes for $3.20 a pop. <br><br>I would liken the experience to what eating dry ice would be. It simply sublimes in the mouth and vaporizes. Imagine cheese that does that? It absolutely defies logic but it&#39;s really interesting. I was confused and surprised for a bit on my first mouth. We had the caramel one and it wasn&#39;t too sweet (which is great). Go try it for yourself.

With the kitchen and ovens helmed by Chef Yamashita and his disciple, Heidi, Flor&#39;s Pâtisserie is a pretty picture of a little cake store sitting upon Duxton Hill. It is completely unassuming and humble in its simplicity but selling hand-made and heart-made delicate desserts that can sweeten up anyone&#39;s day.<br><br>While many of us here in Singapore are used to French style desserts in which tastes are heavier and richer, Heidi shares that Flor&#39;s Pattiserie is all about Kansai-styled pastries: light, fluffy and working with loads of fruits. <br><br>It is ridiculous if I said everything in the display was good? Probably not at Flor&#39;s. Particularly note worthy Earl Grey Chocolat and the Waguri Millefeuille. It is hard to find cake with good chestnut cream in SG. This is where you can get it.<br><br>Also, pack home some iced cheese tarts in a variety of flavours home to share. Your family will love you for it!

text: A tiny, quaint bakery and cafe on Duxton hill, the cakes here are as pretty as they are delicious. <br><br>I love the attention to detail and the decorating is exquisite, making it almost seem like a sin to stab these beautifully presented cakes with a fork. <br><br>Looking through the showcase at this selection, it was extremely difficult to make a decision, but we eventually settled on the millefeuille and strawberry soufflé. The latter was delightfully moist, whilst the millefeuille was surprisingly light even with the layers of pastry. <br><br>We were extremely happy with both our choices, and I certainly look forward to returning to try more of their creations.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/BnHxZcnZb0G_17HkyjERQA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/flor-patisserie-singapore?reviewid=GedClZxnx2SeLjcoAP-BpA&select=BnHxZcnZb0G_17HkyjERQA', 'altText': 'Photo of Flor Patisserie - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: If you have a sweet tooth and a dying love for cakes, then Flor Patisserie will be your desired place to go to!<br><br>The kitchen helm by renowned Chef Yamashita, you know you&#39;ll never go wrong with your choice at Flor Patisserie. My friends introduced it to me and I finally got to try the cakes a few weeks back, during a birthday celebration.<br><br>I tried the Wakakusayama (green tea base) and the Mont Blanc. Honestly, I didn&#39;t really like the green tea one as the taste of matcha was too overwhelming for me. This is just a personal opinion as I&#39;m never a big fan of green tea. The only tea I enjoy is Winter Melon Tea.<br><br>Anyway, the Mont Blanc was fabulous! The cake is soft and so yummy! I loved it. I also ate most of the birthday boy&#39;s cake. Too hard to resist if you ask me.

text: Awesome cakes with the right amount of sweetness and fluff! The only thing is the place is a bit small so it is only good for small group of people :) I love their chestnut cake!

Hmm. I&#39;m a little torn rating this place.<br><br>My friends and relatives love it, but it just doesn&#39;t hit the spot for me. The cakes are indeed good by objective standards - light and fluffy but not floury, well-balanced flavours, not too sweet, not too creamy. But I prefer richer and heavier cakes that make you sick when you eat too much of them.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/QAkESKMA0QgfW0Zfu43T_g/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/flor-patisserie-singapore?reviewid=WdkcrdqiUz9ZLwCtbhCjWg&select=QAkESKMA0QgfW0Zfu43T_g', 'altText': 'Photo of Flor Patisserie - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: This little cake shop  is located in the increasingly popular Duxton Hill.  The japanese styled cakes served here are very similar to that of Glace Pastisserie but with a difference touch. After all, Chef Yamashita did a stint at Glace before opening up Flor. <br><br>I find that the cakes served here are more fruity themed.  The cakes are pretty and delicious yet not overly done up with cream and fondant.  <br><br>Unlike Glace where it has only has a storefront, Flor has some limited dine-in space for customers.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=ZEB-iJxQ4Qxg-QUsyVKGdA', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/gfILpqxit2zBjuODctVdMQ/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/gfILpqxit2zBjuODctVdMQ/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/gfILpqxit2zBjuODctVdMQ/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/gfILpqxit2zBjuODctVdMQ/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/gfILpqxit2zBjuODctVdMQ/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/gfILpqxit2zBjuODctVdMQ/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Kevin B.', 'displayLocation': 'Long Island City, Queens, NY', 'altText': 'Kevin B.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=ZEB-iJxQ4Qxg-QUsyVKGdA', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 4, 'photoCount': 1, 'reviewCount': 15, 'eliteYear': None}
text: I would like to tell you how the food tasted, but I was turned away at 8:23 pm tonight when the staff told me &#34;only take-away. We close at 8:30.&#34; Upon pointing out the sign that says 9PM, she said &#34;The store closes at 9, but the cafe closes at 8:30.&#34; Such attitude. I was disgusted at the lack of grace from a supposed Japanese restaurant. Won&#39;t be going back to be treated poorly again.

Flor has got to be my favorite cake shop. Opened by Chef Yamashita, who is Japanese, it is a French-Japanese cake shop that has the most delicate and exquisite cakes. It is as if they are the exact opposite of the cakes you get at neighborhood shops of coarse and simple flour and eggs.<br><br>The shop is located on the sleepy stretch of Duxton Hill and has a blue signboard. It is also diagonally opposite Littered With Books, an indie bookstore. Note that the place closes at 7pm and runs out of cakes quite early so be sure to go early too!<br><br>Try the strawberry cream cake and Mille feuille. I find their chocolate cakes slightly too rich/sweet. I prefer their lighter creations instead.

Led by Chef Yamashita who learnt his baking tricks from Japan, you can be sure to find some authentically Japanese pastries in this little cafe along the swanky Tanjong Pagar area. <br><br>Japanese pastries differ from their Western counterparts because of the careful attention to detail, and lack of reliance on artificial elements such as baking powder and preservatives. Each piece of pastry in Flor, especially the cakes, is a carefully assembled masterpiece that sometimes look too good to eat. But don&#39;t worry, they taste as good as they look. I usually order any cake that is a combination of sponge, fruits and cream, as I&#39;m a fan of the Japanese style of baking such cream cakes - the texture and flavour of the light sponge, tart fruits and non-cloying cream is delicious. (I&#39;ve made it a point to never order such cakes from non-Japanese bakeries as I&#39;ve had many bad experiences)<br><br>The staff are friendly and approachable, which makes this place a delight to visit every time!

text: I&#39;ve recently became a fan of cheese tarts and popped by this place after hearing about it from a friend. Their &#34;Ice Cheese Tarts&#34; is OK for me, not overly sweet but lack the &#34;oomph&#34; I would normally expect. The almond crust was good and made up for the lack of cheese-:)

text: For my birthday, my friends decided to get me this amazing chestnut cream cake with crunchies and fruit on it.  It was possibly one of the most delicious cakes I have ever had.  The sponge was light in texture and deliciously moist. The chestnut mousse was amazingly balanced in creaminess and sweetness. The crunches (cereal?) adds an added layer of texture in the cake. Overall... yes, I&#39;m in love, and I don&#39;t even like cakes that much! Excellent option for a cake!

text: It&#39;s been awhile since my last visit to Flor Patisserie but that doesn&#39;t mean I can&#39;t write a review about it based on my previous few trips and unique experiences. <br><br>Let&#39;s start with the food, or in this case, pastries. <br><br>Cakes! Tarts! Cookies! This place is a haven for all with a sweet tooth. Not only will you be able to satisfy your dessert craving here (minus ice-cream though, you&#39;ll have to go to a Cold Stone or a 7-11 for that), you&#39;ll be getting your money&#39;s worth for the quality of each heavenly delight you put into your mouth. Why? Simple, if you&#39;ve been to Japan, you&#39;ll know that their pastries are to die for and lo and behold! Flor Patisserie is a Japanese-styled patisserie serving authentic Japanese inspired French pastry and that&#39;s a mathematical combination that every living, breathing person would know the answer to. <br><br>Personal favourites for me would be the Earl Grey Choco ($6.95), Marron Pie ($4.50), Madeleine ($2.15/pc, any flavour) &amp; of course, Flor&#39;s signature Ice Cheese Tarts ($3.40/pc, 9 flavours to choose from -  for all cheese lovers, its frozen cheese on a tart, heaven! )<br><br>According to the description on the website, the Earl Grey Choco is a &#34;Delicate earl grey cream piped onto swiss roll of dark chocolate meringue and sweet banana&#34; - it&#39;s pretty much that except this written description doesn&#39;t exactly give you the idea of how soft and airy the texture is, despite having a meringue casing around it. The Earl Grey cream is not too rich which makes it easier to go with the candied bananas. I actually raved about this one slice so much that my friends got me a whole roll for my birthday one of the years, much to my delight - we should all embrace getting a year older with some good cake! <br><br>The Marron Pie (it&#39;s muffin sized)  was an interesting surprise for me personally. I&#39;m not much of a chestnut fan so when I first discovered that there was a chestnut in the heart of this, I pretty much passed on the idea. But my friend, who introduced the place to me, kept raving about it and described how she would savour this (nibbling on it for hours apparently), I thought I&#39;d give it a go and if i didn&#39;t like it, my late-mother was a fan of chestnuts so she could have it. Unfortunately for her, it never made it home. <br>&#34;&#34;Description: Buttery fragrant almond cream baked in crunchy puff pastry cup with sweetened japanese chestnut center.&#34; Damn right, it&#39;s as tasty as that! But don&#39;t let the word &#39;buttery&#39; fool ya, it&#39;s not overwhelming, unlike some other baked goods I&#39;ve tried. Instead, the butter is more like a coat over the crunchiness of the puff pastry and the almond cream which combined together, does a good number on your taste buds, that just leaves you yearning for more. Not fantastic for the waistline because this thing is HUGE but if you have a little fat girl inside you somewhere, you should be nice and treat her to a something every now and then &amp; I highly recommend this to be it. <br><br>Madeleine. This brings me to my unique experience as well but first,  these are not at all dry and the chocolate ones are moist, almost similar to a brownie or a chocolate lava cake minus the lava. Back to the story, at one point,  they were selling the Madeleines in the shape of bears, individually wrapped which was adorable and so, I decided to buy some back. That same evening, I discovered mold on one of the bear&#39;s ear and decided to let them know about it. I wasn&#39;t expecting anything but I just thought I&#39;d let them know of my find. I called the very next day and to my surprise, I got a tonne of sincerely apologetic replies back, it almost made me feel bad for making the call. They offered to give me something for free on my next visit but I wasn&#39;t gonna be going back anytime within that week so I just left it. On my next visit however, the Madeleines were back to being the shell shaped ones and so I briefly mentioned the bears and that I found mold on one of them once. THAT immediately sparked an wave of acknowledgment around the room and after discussing amongst themselves, the lady serving me apologized and gave me another Madeleine free to make up for it, shortly after, the chef himself came out from the kitchen to apologize and explained that it was an error on their part for not sealing the packaging properly, resulting in the air to enter the pack and thus, mold. I thought that that was VERY professional of them to acknowledge this and to even have the chef himself come out personally. Needless to say, as with all Japanese service staff, everyone (including the chef), saw me out of the cafe before resuming their respective duties. <br><br>Like I said, it has been awhile since I&#39;ve been back there &amp; i do believe the prices have increased a little. However, after writing about it and reliving all these amazing  memories about the pastries and the place, I&#39;m pretty sure i&#39;ll be back there soon, this time with a good book, to chill, enjoy some cake, have a good cuppa tea......and then hit the gym after.

text: EatUp at @theassemblyground<br><br>APPETIZER<br>Salted Yolk Calamari (S$15++)<br>Crumbled fried calamari tossed with salted egg yolk, chilli padi, curry leaves<br><br>MAIN<br>Barramundi Bouillabaisse (S$24++)<br>Pan-fried barramundi, white clams, blue mussels, squid in light &amp; clear French seafood broth<br>The broth was the best part.<br><br>Slipper Lobster Barramundi Laksa (S$28++)<br>Slipper lobster, pan-fried barramundi, coconut curry, fried wonton strips, quail eggs, fish cake, beancurd puffs<br>Quite rich and creamy while not too spicy although would prefer it in thick bee hoon. Lovely texture by the crispy wonton skin.<br><br>PASTA<br>Crab Pomodoro (S$24++)<br>Spaghetti, jumbo lump crabmeat, shaved parmigiana, spicy pomodoro sauce with a touch of cream<br>Lots of chunky crabmeat although got to beware of the bird&#39;s eye chilli. Think  it&#39;s the most spicy of all the dishes we have tonite.<br><br>Truffle Carbonara (S$24++)<br>Fettuccine, shiitake &amp; white button mushrooms, porcini cream sauce, poached egg, shaved parmigiana, truffle paste<br>The crowd favourite although sadly the slightly too firm yolk didn&#39;t flow as expected.<br><br>BURGER <br>Bom Chika Wow Wow (S$20++)<br>Fried chicken, fried egg, vintage cheddar, pear slaw, pickled daikon, truffle mayo <br><br>DESSERT <br>Apple Crumble (S$12++)<br>New Zealand vanilla bean ice cream <br><br>Sticky Ondeh Pudding (S$13++)<br>Pandan sticky pudding, gula melaka coconut filling, New Zealand vanilla bean ice cream<br>Interesting to find filling inside the pudding. Even with the sauce, it was not too sweet. The combination of the slightly hot pudding and cold ice cream was great. Plus crumbles for additional texture.<br><br>BEVERAGE <br>Coconut Dalgona (S$8++)<br>Most only heard of Dalgona which is made of frothy coffee on top of milk. The version here got coffee jelly in it plus bits of desiccated coconut.

text: Chili crab mac &amp; cheese ($18) - 3.75 stars<br><br>American duck pizza ($22) - 3.75 stars<br><br>Skinny green tea latte ($6.50)<br>No soy milk here.<br><br>Note that the prices don&#39;t include the 7% GST.<br><br>Ambience - 2 stars<br>I don&#39;t usually comment on this. In this case it&#39;s a negative. Way too dark to read inside and the music was loud and annoying. It gave me a headache.

text: Located right on the ground floor of Cathay is this hipster looking cafe. One must wonder how much do they make, to afford rent in such a prime location! <br><br>But nonetheless, the staff greeted me politely as I walked in and showed me to a table.The bicycles on the walls were very strategically placed above each table with rather dim lighting. The whole cafe has a very rustic feel to it.<br><br>As I was waiting for the movie to start, I decided to just grab a cuppa and this matcha latte hits the spot! Perfect mix of green tea and sweetness. The aroma itself woke me up! I am definitely getting another cup of matcha latte here! <br><br>All in all, a great place to chill out without burning a hole in your pocket.

text: The coffee is 4-star but the food is miserable so 3 star it is. <br><br>The place is crowded on weekends and you can leave your name and contact number if you wish to wait for one. They will call you once a table frees up. <br><br>On weekdays it gets crowded during lunch time but it is not horribly noisy that you cannot hear yourself think. <br><br>The place decor is typical of so many others with a bit of industrial look and with wooden furnishings. Still a nice place for a cup of coffee, but not necessary a comfortable place to chill with a book. <br><br>The food menu looks appetizing, unfortunately the sandwich I had was pathetic (see pics). There was so little meat that you could count the small pieces dotting the bread. No wonder I thought I was just eating two slices of bread. Maybe it was a one- off time but I did not go back to try again.

Beef rendang Mac and cheese.. the combination is pure genius!', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Beef rendang Mac and cheese.. the combination is pure genius!'}]
text: My new favorite brunch place in the city area. Spacious location, well spaced tables, friendly staff are just a start. The real magic is in their food. Great ingredients and excellent combinations. We got the assembly brunch and the rendang Mac and cheese and we were beyond delighted with the food. It was timely, hot when served and the portions were generous. Pair it with one of their smoothies and you may be set for a wonderful day ahead.

Beef cheek pappardelle', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Beef cheek pappardelle'}]
text: Used the Entertainer app to get a free main here - do note that burgers and sandwiches are t included in this deal. <br><br>We ordered beef cheek pappardelle and a roast chicken, along with some iced osmanthus teas. After discount the total was $30 which wasn&#39;t a bad deal. <br><br>Food is tasty and decent quality, though rather small portioned. <br><br>The beef cheek was tender, though I would&#39;ve preferred it in more of a &#34;ragu&#34; style rather than in chunks. I&#39;m not sure why shiitake mushrooms were used - it didn&#39;t go quite so well. The pasta was apparently house made and quite nice. <br><br>Chicken leg was well seasoned and tasty but potatoes were under-seasoned. <br><br>Overall not bad but without the Entertainer discount, I don&#39;t think it would&#39;ve been worth he price.

text: This cafe is spacious and has a nice decor and has self service free flow of ice water.<br><br>What I like is that I can have buy-1-get-1-free for the mains with the Entertainer app here, which means it&#39;s only $20 plus for 2 pax. <br><br>The food quality is okay but the serving of the rosti could be more. The fries are thin and crispy and the type that can get quite addictive.

text: A popular bistro within The Cathay, The Assembly Ground serves up really good pizza and pasta. To top it up, they serve pretty good lattes and they all come with a scoop of vanilla ice cream!<br><br>I personally really like the Matcha Latte. With a scoop of ice cream, it&#39;s really a filling dessert! The pizzas are thin crusted and i really enjoy the duck and arugula pizza. Good for about 3 pax to share together with a serving of a side to add variety to the meal. <br><br>The idea of truffle fries is always very appealing. Lightly salted with truffle salt, that&#39;s pretty much they have to offer here at The Assembly Ground. Not the best that I have tasted, really just enough to give you a good whiff of the truffle on regular fries.<br><br>More food to try, I hope to be back soon.

text: Edit: deleted a star because a $8 cup of iced latte seriously should not be that tiny! I guess I&#39;m paying for this little dainty sprig of flowers in an empty lemonade jar on my table. I&#39;d rather head to Starbucks right across next time I think. <br><br>Came here to chill for a few hours before a movie, and loved the experience! Can&#39;t speak to the food which some other reviews comment negatively on, but I&#39;ll be back next time for coffee &amp; to chat with friends. <br><br>The ambiance and design is the hipster/woody style and I loved it - tables are placed a comfortable distance away, and the staff don&#39;t make you feel uncomfortable for just whiling away a few hours here. They have free wifi &amp; iced water &amp; many tables. It&#39;s the type of cafe I&#39;ve seen at more inaccessible places like Tiong Bahru and Tanjong Pagar, so I&#39;m very glad this is so close to a major MRT station! <br><br>We ordered 1 for 1 iced cooler promotion ($5 for both), honey cabana &amp; osmanthus. Both were served in mason jars &amp; looked very thin and watery but quite tasty and light! Very refreshing. Also shared brownies, a popular item on the menu according to the friendly staff, which were delicious ($6.50). I was craving a coffee so I also ordered an iced latte ($8), which came with a scoop of vanilla ice cream inside. I was a little disappointed about the size of this - it&#39;s a small glass maybe 8oz? (Def smaller than the Tall at Starbucks). But the coffee was strong and good. <br><br>The baked goods at the counter (not in the refrigerater) are freshly homemade: selections included Thai milk tea cake, brownies, citrus loaf, and they looked very good!!

The Assembly Ground used to be one of my haunts when I worked in the city area. The coffee was good, meals were a bit pricey and the portions were a little on the small side. <br><br> Revisiting this place after about a year, I was disappointed by how far the quality had fallen. I had their set meal - chicken skewers with aglio olio pasta which came with the soup of the day and a choice of drink. <br><br>The soup of the day was pumpkin- way too sweet although the texture was nice. <br><br>The main was... a joke. The pasta was barely enough for my 15 year old nephew and parts of the chicken were undercooked. <br><br>On a more positive note, some of my friends who ordered the ala carte said their food was good. <br><br>Avoid their set meals at all costs.

text: This cafe is located on the ground floor of the Cathay. It does have a very hipster feel and look to it but is more frequented by random shoppers in the area. Service was nice, friendly and fast (but I struggled to understand the Singlish that the staff were speaking) <br><br>They serve up some standard pastas and pizzas but also a very good wagyu burger that I can strongly recommend. That is the standout dish as most other things are pretty average. They serve coffee from Nylon so the beans are clearly of good quality and they are pretty decent and making the coffee here but by no means the best place in town. If you are however in the area this is a good place to go for your caffeine fix.<br><br>They have free wifi and it can be nice to sit and slack in the sofas by the entrance for a while before heading out for more shopping. All in all a nice place if you are in the area but not worth to actively travel to.

text: This is their Rosti Benedict ($17). Looks good and taste wise is not bad. Friends ordered their Assembly Brunch ($20), Rendang Mac and Cheese ($18) and Rotisserie Chicken ($18). The Rendang Mac and Cheese smells really nice ! The assembly brunch have really a large portion. The Rotisserie Chicken taste good. The chicken is very tender. Once in a while, spending this much.

The Assembly Wagyu Burger (S$24.50)', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'The Assembly Wagyu Burger (S$24.50)'}]
text: I didn&#39;t try their coffee, so no comment on that. This is a review on their The Assembly Wagyu Burger ($24.50). I don&#39;t really like beef, but I ordered their wagyu burger nonetheless cos I heard some good reviews about it. I am so glad that I did take a chance cos their wagyu burger was really good. All the burgers menu was served with sesame brioche bun + spiced fries. The sesame brioche bun was very very good. It was toasted with just enough butter, and it was still warm though it had been sitting for more than 10 mins after being served. Since it comes with fries, so for girls, you might have some difficulty to finish this dish. I came there HUNGRY (it was past 12 pm and I haven&#39;t eaten anything since morning) and yet I couldn&#39;t finish the dish. But I guess being served too much food is better than being served too little food, right? ;p<br><br>About the wagyu beef patty it was very thick - however texture wise it was perfect. I could easily cut &amp; chew it with no problem at all. No complains. Taste wise it was very good as well. It was juicy and just right salty. Though I really like this dish overall very much, I can testify that the fries (though also tasted good) but was loaded with lots of MSG (I got very very thirsty afterwards) drinking like 6 cups of water total. So if you were on diet, it&#39;s probably a good idea to just skip the fries and go straight to the burger. <br><br>My hubby got Ragout of Beef with Rosti (S$23). Based on the menu description, it was slow-roasted angus, rosti, trio of mushrooms, onion jam, creamed spinach, &amp; 62C egg. When it came to our table, the smell was very nice and tempting. However when it comes to the taste, the beef was very lacking. In conclusion, if you&#39;re feeling to eat smth beef-y, I vote for the wagyu beef burger all the way!<br><br>Last but not least the place has ample seating space. They also offer free wifi for customers, however when I tried it (Assembly 1) it doesn&#39;t work... :/ [came here on July 11]

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/z6uAZHzzcGlYWChwvoYUjQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-assembly-ground-singapore?reviewid=hc25tiDqKsB1A4zfvxYF6Q&select=z6uAZHzzcGlYWChwvoYUjQ', 'altText': 'Photo of The Assembly Ground - Singapore, Singapore. Tasty and a good value for weekday lunch', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Tasty and a good value for weekday lunch'}]
text: Definitely a nice spot for refueling or hang out at the Cathy and much better than the restaurants downstairs, Assembly Ground is right next to Assembly Store, which happens to be a neat men&#39;s store.  I stopped by for lunch after some shopping and was pleasantly surprised by a very nice lunch set.  For $15, I was able to enjoy a nice cauliflower veloute, a sandwich or pasta, french fries, a small salad, and a iced tea!  Although it&#39;s available only on weekdays and there are no substitutions for coffee, it&#39;s a great deal, when even a single a la carte sandwich in Toa Payoh can easily cost $14.  I went with the tuna salad sandwich, and while it wasn&#39;t revolutionary I definitely enjoyed the lunch set as a whole and went back for some espresso, which was just perfect.  I bet the place gets packed on weekends and in the evenings, but it&#39;s also a nice spot for a quiet weekday lunch or coffee as well!

I&#39;ve been in here a few times, always on my way to see a movie at The Cathay. Why? For me, it&#39;s all about the beer. They usually have 2 taps of Archipelago&#39;s small batch beer, which is a perfect pre- (or post-) movie drink. The desserts are good, too. I love their sticky date pudding. And I&#39;ve been told that their coffee is quite nice...<br>It&#39;s been popular every time I&#39;ve been there, so it gets a bit noisy for my taste. But I&#39;m an old guy, so consider the source. ;-)

text: Nice setting and central location that is not overrun with crowds. There seems to be live music at certain timings. The colorful metal chairs are actually more comfortable than they look. I had matcha latte which was fragrant. The latte art is not bad. Food wise the portion and ingredients were decent but not spectacular. It is not a place that I will specially go to for the food but it is a good option if you are in town and want to relax somewhere without burning a huge hole in the wallet.

text: The ambience is all good; really nice place to hang out with friends.<br><br>Staff was really patient while my friend and I worked our way through the menu + decide on which cake to get. Price is pretty reasonable. Didn&#39;t get to try the coffee that everyone seems to rave about as we were not up for caffeine, but the facilities/coffee machine looks amazing + barista seems professional even with our drinks (camomile honey lemon tea + green tea latte that comes with a scoop of vanilla ice cream).<br><br>Can&#39;t stop popping the pop corn chicken and the assembly brunch&#39;s cheesy potato layer is simply addictive. Definitely recommend for people who just wanna chill in a café on a lazy afternoon.

* Last Order at 9pm, do note that cash register will be closed so meaning not even cakes can be ordered.<br><br>Ordered Smoked Duck Pasta ($17-18)<br>It&#39;s done very simply with a medley of vegetables and the duck of course. I didnt quite enjoy the dish(could do with more garlic and seasoning) but my partner enjoyed my leftovers.<br><br>My group shared Truffle Fries which was more satisfying than the above. The cafe offers a variety of cakes and tarts though the menu doesnt state so.<br><br>The takeback of this visit would be if you order a burger, it comes with a free pint! Do check with the server on the validity of the promo.

Brought my daughter here today for lunch. We had the portobello burger n spicy sausage pasta. Both are below average.  The pasta particular tasted like instant noodle throw in few slices of beacon n sausage.  The service also was lousy. <br><br>This is my first time here n probably last time too.

text: Cute décor and decent food.<br><br>I&#39;m surprised there hasn&#39;t been more reviews for this place. The name definitely came up often on other sites and blogs. My friend and I came here for brunch on a Sunday. The location is quite convenient and easy to find in the Cathay. The food was presented nicely but tasted just okay. So are the lattes. I would give 3.5 stars overall if possible but round up for the nice and chic design.

text: Nice chocolate drink. Noisy place. Expensive mains. Serving so-so lar. Martini Lychee did not give any martini kick at all.

text: Overall, I&#39;d say this isn&#39;t someplace I&#39;d purposely seek out again. I dined here with 2 friends in the late afternoon before catching a movie upstairs. We were seated at the long table in the back, which had 3-4 trays of what appeared to be the remnants of the staff lunch on the other half of it. Also, it seemed to be their unofficial break area, which just didn&#39;t give us the relaxing vibe we were looking for. <br><br>As for the food, some dishes were better than others. The calamari could have come from a convenience pack, and the hae bi hiam pasta was dry and had one measly shrimp. The chicken burger was good though, and the truffle carbonara tasty though pricey for what was essentially a meatless dish with cheap mushrooms (shimeji &amp; shitake). There was also unfortunately a hair in my iced latte.

text: Chic cafe in a half dead mall.<br><br>They had a 1 for 1 lunch promo for Mondays, choice of pasta or pizza. We ordered a Beef Chilli Fettuccine and a Spicy Sausage and Bacon. <br><br>The Spicy Sausage pasta was delicious and did not taste spicy at all. The beef Chilli on the hand was just okay. <br><br>Its a partial service eatery, you have to place your order at the cashier and they will serve your dishes. You can help yourself to some water at the far end of the cafe.<br><br>Lovely ambience to chill with friends. The promotion makes it affordable to dine there, without the promotion not quite sure if it&#39;s worth it.

Spicy Beef Pasta', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Spicy Beef Pasta'}]
text: Assemble it is.  Place is cosy I suppose really good for people to hang out to eat, talk and perhaps even do some work.  Had lunch there and got to say it was good.  Got the pulled chicken sandwich.  Came hot, nicely grilled toasted with crispy fries and side of salad.  Wife and boy had the spicy beef and the spicy sausage pastas and they were done just rite. Exact words from my better half.... Better value than Cedele!!???  Oh oh....watch out Cedele.  All in all service at least from the recept to the table was attentive and taking of order was super easy.   Best of all water is free this is getting to be a rare commodity.  We&#39;ll be back for sure.

Great little place for a quick bite in the Cathay. I opted for a burger and it was very, very good. The fries were excellent as well. As it was Sunday evening, it was pretty quiet and we had no problem getting a seat of enjoying a great conversation. I will definitely go back!

Errm .. Iced latte with a scoop of vanilla ice creme - kinda pointless if I&#39;d wanted a low fat iced cappuccino (but they don&#39;t have that) right? Decent coffee if not spectacular - too much milk to taste the coffee. Not related to Assembly at Evans Road.

I arrived at assembly ground on a weekday evening and it was relatively empty with a few groups of people enjoying cups of coffee. While I know their coffee is recommended, I&#39;ve never been a huge fan of coffee. So, I hesitated ordering a cup expecting my coffee addict of a boyfriend to order one that I can try a tiny bit of. However, he surprised me by ordering a pint...a latte it was for me, and a good thing I did too. The coffee was a good blend in my opinion, less acidic and with a great robust flavour. The milk tasted somewhat creamy which made me slightly suspicious but all in all, it was a good drink. My friend also seemed to thoroughly enjoy her ice chocolate, for those who don&#39;t particularly like coffee. I had the coney dog, while my boyfriend had the blackened tuna burger and my friend ordered the beef ragout with rosti. I wouldn&#39;t say it was spectacular, just a regular frankfurter it seems with a slightly sweeter than expected beef chilli but it fulfilled my chilli dog craving and as such, I&#39;d give it 3 stars. The remaining star comes from the fact that my companions seemed to quite enjoy their food and the decent portions, and we were served by an exceptionally friendly waiter, who was key to our whole experience being delightful overall. To that waiter, you might think you&#39;re just doing your job but thank you for doing it so well!

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/AczFJe6FzCkBdHR9Y2F4UQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/botanist-singapore?reviewid=Hd5BeK_OsPDwVXHGmiugOw&select=AczFJe6FzCkBdHR9Y2F4UQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Botanist - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: I enjoyed it. Bit of a surprise as I didn&#39;t know about this place, happened to walk by it when hungry.<br><br>I walked in on a weekday lunch hour and found the place just opened for the day. Ordered the Avocado Toast dish and an iced americano then took a seat out in the garden patio area.<br><br>They brought out the plate and it was just beautiful to look at, almost didn&#39;t want to eat it. This easily was the best tasting (and looking) Avocado Toast I&#39;ve ever eaten. Highly recommend.<br><br>Although having the main entrance on the side street is a bit of a nuisance. Otherwise it&#39;s a great cafe to hang and grab a bite!

text: Great spot for a delicious bite to eat, breakfast, brunch, or lunch. Nice ambiance on the front patio, and an upstairs area with sitcom for the hot days.<br>The food doesn&#39;t disappoint, and lots of greenery growing on the modern cement walls.

text: Very chill ambiance with beautiful aesthetics. The food here is delicious, and they had a lot on their menu that I wanted to try. We went around brunch time and my husband got the soft shell crab burger. It was very tasty. I got the salmon tartine which was beautifully presented and equally as delicious.

Looks great from the pics and menu online. We arrived and got a seat right away, however when we ordered, most things were sold out and the waitress stated that our food would take 50 min (Eggs and French toast) - why it would take so long boggles my mind. We decided to order drinks and leave. Bad business if they have such a problem w/cook times and turning tables.

the place is absolutely beautiful - everything from interior design and the way each dish is plated. great attention to details, and the food tasted great too!<br><br>will definitely come back to try more

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=xU3sDPonLx1_w4t6wOOpdg', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/2tpNJsz2hcEol8OYpL7nSQ/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/2tpNJsz2hcEol8OYpL7nSQ/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/2tpNJsz2hcEol8OYpL7nSQ/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/2tpNJsz2hcEol8OYpL7nSQ/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/2tpNJsz2hcEol8OYpL7nSQ/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/2tpNJsz2hcEol8OYpL7nSQ/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Ting Yi C.', 'displayLocation': 'Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Ting Yi C.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=xU3sDPonLx1_w4t6wOOpdg', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 30, 'photoCount': 6, 'reviewCount': 194, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Although the place is quite crowded on weekends, the great service and ambience makes up for it! There is not GST/service charge so you pay whatever is on the menu. The outside of the cafe makes for a good backdrop for outfit photos too.

Yes there is a Coffeebean on Sentosa.<br><br>If you are an Sentosa Islander member, you get additional 10% off.<br><br>It probably tastes the same here as everyone else of the Coffeebean, just at 10% off.

After spending the day in Sentosa, my friend and I decided to get some lunch at the Coffee Bean and Tea Leaf. It is a small place but clean and the service is efficient. My friend took some time to make her choice but I decided to have a slice of the salmon quiche (somewhat small but nonetheless tasty) and a caffe latte. My friend opted for a glass of unsweetened ice tea and the Mediterranean sandwich which she said was also very good. If you are in Sentosa for the day and want a quick snack or lunch, this is an ideal place to stop in. It is reasonably priced and I would recommend.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/sCfyWNZIArWX-5kcq8WGoQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/toast-box-singapore-24?reviewid=L8HEwBeSmo5AToMLLWc8Gg&select=sCfyWNZIArWX-5kcq8WGoQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Toast Box - Singapore, Singapore. Braised pork rice with chicken leg and iced tea', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Braised pork rice with chicken leg and iced tea'}]
text: Diagonally across from Hotel G, the modern look of this eatery caught my attention. Although it says on the website that it is a Singaporean lifestyle place, I got the impression that was more of a hodgepodge of Asian food. Dishes varied from chicken curry to braised pork rice bowls. <br><br>It was a little awkward when I ordered as the guy at the counter barely spoke any English. Apparently, the iced tea that I ordered carried an additional surcharge of $0.50 SGD. <br><br>The food was pretty good for fast casual food. Basically, everything is pre-made and was slopped onto my plate. Despite the fact that it was pre-made, it was still pretty decent regardless and nicely presented. Note, there was air conditioning in this place but some a**hole left the door open letting that precious cold air out escape out the door.

text: - Super busy place, no matter the time<br>- Menu above the cashier did not match the menu the full menu available <br>- No restroom available<br>- Fast food style( tray service), but not the prices <br>- If visiting Singapore, kaya toast is must try! <br>- Would not recommend!

Other menu items', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Other menu items'}]
text: I love Toast Box in Singapore. They do have franchises in other countries. But, they just don&#39;t taste as good compared to the ones in Singapore. I have to get their Kopi-C here, which is basically their blend of aromatic coffee with creamy and sweet condensed milk. Better than any Starbucks chain. <br><br>As for their breakfast options, I really don&#39;t go for their sweet options. I have tried most of their savory items. My favorite items to order for a hearty breakfast were their Nasi Lemak, Curry Chicken Rice, and my sister&#39;s favorite, their braised pork over rice with a roasted chicken leg on the side. All of these dishes were brimming with flavor and packed a wonderful punch. I appreciated that the rice that came with these dishes was aromatic and not mushy. Other noteworthy dishes that were pretty good were their laksa and mee goreng. The noodles in the laksa were broken up into pieces for easy eating. But, this didn&#39;t allow much of that laksa broth flavor to be absorbed. We just prefer their spaghetti type noodles more, as far as flavor and texture goes. The laksa broth was also a little bit too creamy from all the coconut milk, in our opinion. The mee goreng noodles were a bit over cooked when I tried it, and the flavor was a little overpowering for me from that shrimp paste. Definitely, cut that strong flavor with the calamansi provided. The pan fried spam was the star of the show in the mee goreng dish.<br><br>Overall, Toast Box is just a wonderful and consistent food option in Singapore to eat breakfast or lunch. It would be dangerous to have a Toast Box close to home, since I practically ate Toast Box almost every morning. Not necessarily good for that waistline. Lol. At least I can splurge on my diet while in Singapore. They&#39;re practically everywhere in Singapore (like an Asian McDonald&#39;s). It&#39;s worth mentioning that their savory items are $8 USD or less. If you&#39;re ever visiting, come check them out.
Tried the sugarcane juice here. The juice was a bit warm and did not taste fresh. Tasted the shakes and those were better.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=dCSfgihxACerBBSGmcHOxA', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/WS_Zf3J7BJmXP-TzlogwAg/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/WS_Zf3J7BJmXP-TzlogwAg/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/WS_Zf3J7BJmXP-TzlogwAg/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/WS_Zf3J7BJmXP-TzlogwAg/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/WS_Zf3J7BJmXP-TzlogwAg/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/WS_Zf3J7BJmXP-TzlogwAg/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Richard B.', 'displayLocation': 'London, United Kingdom', 'altText': 'Richard B.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=dCSfgihxACerBBSGmcHOxA', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 48, 'photoCount': 170, 'reviewCount': 135, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Coffee, Tea, kaya toast, noodles, and everything in between. It seems like they really do everything. <br>I can&#39;t say that they actually do everything well at all. Instead of just focusing on selling things they are good at, they decide to dabble in everything they can get their hands on just to beat their competitors. <br><br>The gold is sub-par, they make you crack your own eggs, and it&#39;s just not a shiok as what OTHER places can offer you.<br><br>All in All. I&#39;m just here for the aircon, and a place to sit.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/r__a74nhs6oLs0l-eq2bLg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/ultra-bake-singapore-4?reviewid=LZj7WVs8M7Xgx0KytTfdfA&select=r__a74nhs6oLs0l-eq2bLg', 'altText': 'Photo of Ultra Bake - Singapore, Singapore. A tiny sliver of a store front', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'A tiny sliver of a store front'}]
text: Do not be intimidated by the daily morning line that might be 30 people deep in the AM, Ulta Bake gets their customers loaded up with fresh baked pastries and cheap coffee at precision conveyor belt speed and gets their customers served quickly. <br><br>This is solely a grab and go spot.  This location is really like a sliver of a location with only a tiny store front.  But the staff is always friendly, the baked items are always well stocked &amp; made fresh daily (off sight I suspect) and the coffee is good.  Everything is super cheap too!  Nothing fancy going on here, just easy, simple, cheap, good baked bread like items. (No cookies or sweets like that, but bread items)<br><br>So a quick AM snack before you head to your work desk in the CBD or just something to nibble on before you head to a park bench near the marina to catch some fresh air, Ulta Bake is simple, easy and OK by me.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/phWkrfCK_dYvk7nT_LFCsQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/va-va-voom-cafe-singapore?reviewid=KQyOTuhvsVspGyKg5B0Vkg&select=phWkrfCK_dYvk7nT_LFCsQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Va Va Voom Cafe - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: Been coming here for the past 5 years now and I love it. It has good ambiance, staff are friendly, food is good, cheap, portions are huge. Like seriously, what more could I ask for? :)<br><br>What I Love: Love the style of the place. It&#39;s very chill, there are couches, pillows and magazines. Games are put in a corner - just in case you&#39;re in the mood for some. Staff are really friendly and sweet - they know me and are very accommodating. The food is gooooooood. I don&#39;t think you can go wrong with anything.<br><br>Try their Summer Rolls. Portions are insane. Plate of 2 (which is cut into 4 pieces) is big enough of a starter for 2 people.<br><br>Their Fried Spring Rolls are yummy too. Not as big as the Summer ones, but good to share as well.<br><br>I&#39;ve tried their salads which are to die for. There&#39;s a Morning Glory Salad with Chicken that&#39;s yummmy. And a Watercress Salad that&#39;s good too. You can order it with Chicken or Beef - but I usually get chicken with this. <br><br>Their Beef Stew is yummmy. I&#39;ve tried their Beef Combo, Beef Brisket and Beef Noodles, all yummy. My fave is the Dry Noodle with Grilled Pork. The pork is served in quite a large portion!<br><br>Fave Fave Dish: Crispy Noodle with Beef on it. It&#39;s really to die for. Portion is huge! So prepare to stuff yourself.<br><br>Drinks: Love their Plum Lime Soda, Calamansi Soda and Vietnamese Coffee. I also like their new teas, Pandan and Lemongrass. Their Lemongrass drink is really yummy too.<br><br>Dessert: Try their Gula Melaka Sago with Coconut Ice-Cream. Yummmmmmy!!!!<br><br>What I Don&#39;t Love: That I can&#39;t eat here everyday! There&#39;s nothing to not love about this place! ;D

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/swAQ0iokOOzBCyO9Q4idqg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/va-va-voom-cafe-singapore?reviewid=DqOkQIWzavwkawWQi_zo4A&select=swAQ0iokOOzBCyO9Q4idqg', 'altText': 'Photo of Va Va Voom Cafe - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/uk6_XrXpmroLKHxc68tC6Q/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/va-va-voom-cafe-singapore?reviewid=DqOkQIWzavwkawWQi_zo4A&select=uk6_XrXpmroLKHxc68tC6Q', 'altText': 'Photo of Va Va Voom Cafe - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: I&#39;m a big fan of Vietnamese cuisine and, having lived in northern Vietnam for a while, I can be picky when trying Vietnamese food elsewhere. <br><br>Va Va Voom is average and doesn&#39;t serve anything close to what you can get in Vietnam, but it&#39;s reasonably priced and the portions are well-sized. <br><br>One of the reasons behind my love affair with Vietnam&#39;s cuisine are the herbs used to heighten flavours in their dishes, and Va Va Voom really falls flat on this one. The pho bo is distinctly lacking in these, as is their fresh spring roll. However, I was quite pleased with their bun with fried spring rolls, and I think I&#39;ll stick with this one the next time I go. <br><br>They have great deals at lunchtime - SGD 9 for a main, drink and ice-cream - and happy hour on their beers and ciders in the early evenings. Because of these aspects, I would say that Va Va Voom is a good choice if you&#39;re on a budget, but don&#39;t expect to be transported to Vietnam with this experience.
