text: So I am a huge dessert fan and I really really wanted to love this place. I&#39;ve posted this review in HungryGoSomewhere and didn&#39;t get a response from the owner. Now with Yelp in Singapore, I need to continue to share my experience.<br><br>They have a great location - I had no clue where &#34;The Foothills&#34; even was? A friend told me that it was near Liang Court but across the street...where? The cafe is super cute. No boring mall location here. It&#39;s tucked away in a side of Fort Canning Park. Ample, comfortable seating. Cute decor - doesn&#39;t look Ikea to me. Oh and their cakes are super attractive looking. If you wanted a beautiful cake for a kids party, adult tea gig, heck, probably even a wedding, this is the place to come (notice that said pretty...which doesn&#39;t mean delicious or tasty). <br><br>That&#39;s about where the compliments end.<br><br>I had this cake a friend&#39;s birthday party and it was decorated like Cookie Monster. There was even a cookie hanging out of the side of Cookie Monster&#39;s face. Looked like a winner to me (remember, I said beautiful cake?). We cut it up and passed around sliced. The icing, I think, was a buttercream that tasted only of butter and maybe a teaspoon of sugar. The best way to describe it would be to imagine mixing a can of Crisco and four sticks of butter together. Now add two teaspoons of sugar. Drown in Smuft blue food coloring. That&#39;s the icing.<br><br>On to the cake. The one we had was a salted caramel chocolate. Cake was tasteless and dry. I appreciated that it came in three layers with caramel in between, which that was nicely flavored. But the caramel wasn&#39;t enough to carry the weak, dry cake, along with lardy icing.<br><br>Even after this bad experience that left everyone&#39;s teeth a bright blue, I wanted to give it another shot for a baby shower I was hosting. The cake&#39;s presentation was super attractive - I can&#39;t fault it for that. Really, it&#39;s an impressive looking cake.<br><br>The following day, I went to the outlet on River Valley. I walked inside of the restaurant and there were three employees there: two friendly women and a shortish man who I can only assume is the &#34;fabulous baker&#34;, owner, or boss during the shift. I asked if I could buy a cake and was told that I needed to order three days in advance. Cool, that&#39;s fine. But then I started asking questions about the cakes in the fridge and none of the three associates wanted to help me. What flavor are these? No response. How many flavors do you have? No response. I&#39;m not sure why these associates froze up or acted awkwardly to my questions.<br><br>I still wanted a cake. I asked if the cakes in the fridge were spoken for. Again, I got stares. Blinks. I pointedly asked the ladies and they told me to ask the shortish man. He said that they weren&#39;t but were to be served in the restaurant, as guests ordered them, sliced. Then I asked that, hypothetically, what if I wanted to buy the ten or twelve slices that would consist of a cake, could he serve them to me. He said that I needed to order cakes three days in advance. Broken record? I heard you the first time, shortish man. In the end, he caved and said that if someone were to come in and ask for ten slices, he would have to sell them to that person.<br><br>So then I asked for ten or twelve slices of the cake in the fridge that weren&#39;t spoken for. The ladies stared at me again and kept blinking. I pressed the question again and they pointed to the shortish man. The shortish man just said he couldn&#39;t sell me the cake. I walked to the door and asked again if they were sure that they didn&#39;t want to sell me the slices and that I would tell my friends and blog about it; this was their last chance to remedy the bad experience I&#39;d had. The shortish man said that no, he was not going to sell me the slices.<br><br>All in all. Great looking cake that tasted sub-par. And horrible service. In Singapore, there are so many great bakeries now. PV Plain Vanilla serves a kick butt cupcake in Holland Village, OKB on Kampong Bahru has the best brownie I&#39;ve probably had in my life, and then you even have Twelve Cupcakes that has recipes for the &#34;Asian palette&#34;. Against these folks, it&#39;s going to be stiff competition for Fabulous Baker Boy.

the very first UYE in SG deserves nothing less!:)<br><br>great place to mingle.<br><br>accommodating staff.<br><br>tuna melt was a winner.<br><br>but meeting laura, marcus, carol, michelle, ancy, cindy, jasmine, xiuru, joshua, smith, charlyn and jia min in person..................................PRICELESS!!!

text: Was there last night and where do I begin? <br><br>1. Fall in love almost immediately with the layout and quirky furnishing. It&#39;s a great place to mingle and events.<br><br>2. The pie was awesome. Had a house pie and I must say I am so bringing people to have this the next time. Of course, while I try something else. but I guess it&#39;s the thing with fresh pies, it took a little longer than I expected to get it served on my table.<br><br>3. The staff there was awesome. Didn&#39;t get to meet the baker boy himself but the coffee boy Haryanto did chat a lil with me. I love staff who will chat a lil and tell us a lil more. And guess what, they don&#39;t even charge us for that. (You will get the joke when you get there.)<br><br>4. Although you might miss the place the 1st few times you pass by but you will never miss it again if you visited it once. It&#39;s actually right opposite Liang Court which means all you have to do is take the MRT to Clarke Quay and cross the road. Simple right? <br><br>5. If the place, the service, price and the food is right, why only 4/5? You didn&#39;t ask but I&#39;m saying anyway. It&#39;s a shame that they only have 1 beer type and 1 cider at this place, when asked, Haryanto mentioned that they have issues with keep a big amount of stock there. tsk tsk. What a shame. <br><br>Overall, I think everyone should at least visit the place once. Cause that is all it takes to get you there again. If you are a fan of &#34;The Pigeon Hole&#34; you will definitely like this place. Of course, &#34;TPH&#34; sells a lot more type of drinks.

text: Truffle fries with garlic aioli was da bomb! Even though I generally don&#39;t like thicker fries this was so good. Will definitely come back for this. $9.50 for a pretty decent sized portion.<br><br>Straits chai tea was too thick for me <br><br>Nice, peaceful atmosphere to waste an afternoon away in. <br><br>Red velvet cake - my friend love this, but personally I&#39;m not a red velvet fan<br><br>Strawberry shortcake - loved this. Definitely one of the better ones I&#39;ve tried. Really like the strawberry jam used as filling <br><br>Really wanna try the sticky date and lemon yoghurt one next time!

text: Bright, modern decor, and sitting on the side of Fort Canning Park across from Clark Quay - this restaurant has so much going for it, but unfortunately the food, coffee, and service are just sadly average. =/

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=YWcvGEfMCkS2H5jvesb2XA', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/4-peO-J7RsgbXGhx98YPeA/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/4-peO-J7RsgbXGhx98YPeA/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/4-peO-J7RsgbXGhx98YPeA/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/4-peO-J7RsgbXGhx98YPeA/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/4-peO-J7RsgbXGhx98YPeA/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/4-peO-J7RsgbXGhx98YPeA/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Jia Min L.', 'displayLocation': 'Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Jia Min L.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=YWcvGEfMCkS2H5jvesb2XA', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 16, 'photoCount': 1, 'reviewCount': 7, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Guiness beef pie was a star. Generous filling of beef &amp; potatos. Would have love a little more variety of root vegetables, but nonetheless the flavours were good. Lovely setting at night when it&#39;s cool. Good place to chill out for sweet &amp; savoury delights.

What great ambience! I can imagine chilling out here, staring at the greenery, feeling as if I am miles away from Singapore city centre! Food was pretty good, I had the chicken curry while my hubby had the eggs Benedict. Main complaint was that it took so long for the food to arrive. There was just one other table at the time but we waited over 10 minutes for a cup of coffee and 45 minutes for the eggs Benedict! As the place filled up, one table got served their food immediately since they where friends with the owner while the rest of us had to wait. Go when you are feeling leisurely and definitely not starved and on an empty stomach!

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=0NjHJNdJPdmc0WHV4VF7fA', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/AhJ8pNx7u3DZLiTp7bSIYg/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/AhJ8pNx7u3DZLiTp7bSIYg/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/AhJ8pNx7u3DZLiTp7bSIYg/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/AhJ8pNx7u3DZLiTp7bSIYg/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/AhJ8pNx7u3DZLiTp7bSIYg/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/AhJ8pNx7u3DZLiTp7bSIYg/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Jaswant T.', 'displayLocation': 'Dhoby Ghaut, Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Jaswant T.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=0NjHJNdJPdmc0WHV4VF7fA', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 54, 'photoCount': 14, 'reviewCount': 7, 'eliteYear': None}
text: ~Location wise~<br>it can be a bit hard to get to if you didn&#39;t google it first. basically its at the foot of fort canning hill directly opposite liang court. (i.e. the opld river valley swimming complex) thanks to google i manage to figure it out<br><br>~ambiance wise~ <br>i would say its more like a tuck shop (i.e toa payoh swimming pool&#39;s tuckshop) there is a choice between indoors and outdoors. Even thou we choose indoors it was still rather humid/hot, and i was like sweating while i was indoors. Outdoor wise i would say even if they had fans they weren&#39;t as powerful to cool someone down. I was there around 2 - 4pm. <br><br>~Service wise~ <br>its abit haphazard, in the sense that going there first they tell you to get a seat, then after they tell you to order at the counter. (most people would expect you to give them a menu if asked to take a seat?). Menu wise rather unprofessional, i mean having a menu printed out and pinned on a board shows the lack of professionalism. i would rather they have wrote it on a black board then printed on paper making it seems so not serious about their food.<br><br>~Price wise~<br>for the same price i think i rather go to TCC/coffee club or some restaurant  in liang court. It&#39;s probbly going to be a try once never go again (unless someone else is paying....) <br><br>~Table wise~ <br>try to avoid the indoors the table is too narrow. My other qualms about the service, Water. basically each table was given water, but maybe cos they lack organisation or were really busy water came to us much later in the meal. (If i didn;t have my own bottle of water i probably would have choke, thou i must say its illogical that the water for 3 people came after the tea i ordered, what happened was a mix of chaos  and lack of a proper system) I witness some other table&#39;s order missing a sausage and stuff (food processing wise i would say they really lack organisation, i mean they asked if we wanted our cake with the food (again what kinda question is this??) and we opted to have it after the food, and they forgot about it, since they processed the first part and threw away the order chit, so when it came to our cakes we have to tell them and get the excuse that they forgot... *sighs*)<br><br>~Food Wise~<br>The only thing they had going for them was the food, i had egg Benedict, it was really tasty but proportion wise i would preferred if their cakes were a bit smaller. I would not recommend going for 2 course (I can really eat, but having both the egg Benedict and the carrot cake really made me skipped dinner)<br><br>~Cake wise~ <br>i had the chance to try 3 of them. their famous red velvet, their carrot cake and their lemon vanilla rasberry. i would say i found their carrot the best, some how the previous reviews had stated their red velvet was nice but i found both the red velvet and Lemon vanilla a tad too dry.  <br><br>Overall i would say its a nice place to go in the evening for tea (after 5 perhaps?) but they fact that when they got busy it shows their lack of a system in place to deal with the orders and the amount of people reflects that there is a lack of organisation.<br><br>this place needs a lot of improvements for it to succeed in the long run.
Well-pulled coffee, excellent location and people watching.  Slightly less attentive service than one might desire, but otherwise great.

text: Cheap and good kopitiam which offers a whole range of local cuisines. Fragrant braised chicken rice is very good but expensive if you want to buy the whole chicken. Rong kee stall at the end is my favourite for wonton noodles as they&#39;re old school and still use lard oil to flavour the dry noodles. <br>The porridge stall serves fluffy Cantonese style chok. The sliced fish is good as well as the pork porridge. But I miss the raw fish platter they used to serve. And the boiled fish skin. They were both drenched in a savoury soya sesame sauce with spring onions and chilli padi. Shiok.<br>At night the three shops are all taken over by zichar shops.

text: I tried the first dish of Singapore, the famous Bak Kut Teh , and this little place sold the best BKT.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/F_lIfHSTs8oAIzkzfDHxYw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/starbucks-singapore-121?reviewid=1elL9NgWDqEZb5hRxVnyEg&select=F_lIfHSTs8oAIzkzfDHxYw', 'altText': 'Photo of Starbucks - Singapore, Singapore. This is their setup in the lobby of the Concourse office tower.', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'This is their setup in the lobby of the Concourse office tower.'}]
text: This is my favorite Starbucks and my regular morning stop. The staff here is Fantastic, although they do seem to regularly rotate new staff in, not sure if this is a training store, or that is just how Starbucks Singapore works; but the core consistent staff is great.<br>They remember my drink, even when I am away traveling for a few weeks or trying a new job for a few months, they pick up right where we left off. They were also great at discussing with me ways to tweak my drink order to find just the drink I was looking for. <br>Plenty of seating and quiet environment I&#39;ve had quite a few meetings here as well.<br>The rewards program is great and freebies are always nice.

Stopped by this place after lunch for some donuts. YUMMY. is the only word I can use. <br><br>I ordered the green tea latte ($6) , ice lemon tea and a latte. <br><br>The green tea latte was absolutely superb. It had a minty taste to it which I really enjoyed and it didn&#39;t leave a bitter after taste which was swell

text: Donuts does not taste like donuts at all!! Tasted like bread with sugary toppings. Real donuts are fried with yeasty taste, these donuts don&#39;t taste like it.<br>Overrated .. nothing special.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/FRZb6elT30ZIEC5Q1jr1Ag/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/j-co-donuts-and-coffee-singapore?reviewid=OF2xodRbPmR_7JGSNT0CdA&select=FRZb6elT30ZIEC5Q1jr1Ag', 'altText': 'Photo of J.Co Donuts & Coffee - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/leTBo4anrIxJwdcTIejBKw/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/j-co-donuts-and-coffee-singapore?reviewid=OF2xodRbPmR_7JGSNT0CdA&select=leTBo4anrIxJwdcTIejBKw', 'altText': 'Photo of J.Co Donuts & Coffee - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/kkb8p7_dReCyaJMEceazlQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/j-co-donuts-and-coffee-singapore?reviewid=OF2xodRbPmR_7JGSNT0CdA&select=kkb8p7_dReCyaJMEceazlQ', 'altText': 'Photo of J.Co Donuts & Coffee - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/9KYpov1R4Dr9YyGSQbSxpQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/j-co-donuts-and-coffee-singapore?reviewid=OF2xodRbPmR_7JGSNT0CdA&select=9KYpov1R4Dr9YyGSQbSxpQ', 'altText': 'Photo of J.Co Donuts & Coffee - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}]
text: mMm...doughnuts!!  And with unique flavors like green tea, lychee, don mochino and tiramisu, how can one resist?!?  the hardest part was narrowing down which flavors to pick but need not to fear....they offer j. pops (aka bite sized donut holes) as a good alternative to try everything.<br><br>if you&#39;re not into sweets, <a href="/redir?url=http%3A%2F%2Fj.co&amp;s=e062400501b8e4b039b63c4d0895b4786fac89d4775c30d95eab17853bf03f56" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">j.co</a> also offers a great selection of espresso drinks as well as sandwiches.  stop by if you&#39;re in the area, they make it super easy to grab a dozen of doughnuts for your coworkers to picking up a quick breakfast/lunch to just sitting down to rest after a day of shopping in Raffles City.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/cgocnV6VYRNOxcYspIG58Q/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/j-co-donuts-and-coffee-singapore?reviewid=Wwxp4f-I5bfRXY8JcinlfA&select=cgocnV6VYRNOxcYspIG58Q', 'altText': 'Photo of J.Co Donuts & Coffee - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: I love eating the Donuts here - they have a really amazing selection! From Green Tea, Cappuccino, Oreo, Cream Stuffed, Sugar Glazed, etc., the list goes on. They have flavors for everyone and their cream filled ones are really yummmmmy. They are not only cream filled but with a generous amount, so when you bite into them, the cream just spills out into your mouth! Truly fab. So much better than Dunkin&#39; Donuts!<br><br>What I Love: Their flavours are pretty cool. I love their cream filled ones, and the crushed Oreo donut. Their prices are pretty amazing. A whole box will only set you back $10, depending on how much you get, I think a good 8 pieces would set you back $10-$12. Which is not so bad. They pack it nicely in a box and I usually give it as a good gift.<br><br>What I Don&#39;t Love: Eating there can be a bit crowded. But apart from that - usually, I just take &#39;em away.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=L5qnan1MZhuF8LetcU-Ziw', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/46gyKGzTxvZuuvKvqp2E8g/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/46gyKGzTxvZuuvKvqp2E8g/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/46gyKGzTxvZuuvKvqp2E8g/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/46gyKGzTxvZuuvKvqp2E8g/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/46gyKGzTxvZuuvKvqp2E8g/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/46gyKGzTxvZuuvKvqp2E8g/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Shu Ling T.', 'displayLocation': 'Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Shu Ling T.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=L5qnan1MZhuF8LetcU-Ziw', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 7, 'photoCount': 347, 'reviewCount': 330, 'eliteYear': None}
text: No one resists a doughnut from J.Co. I repeat, NO ONE! <br><br>I love the doughnuts at J.Co. They are fresh, soft, delectable, everything you expect of a good piece of doughnut! This particular one and Raffles City is quite a good resting spot after shopping for quite a while. There is this sense of tranquility that transcends words when you can finally sit down with a simple sugar glazed doughnut and good cup of cappuccino to rest and take a break from the crowd. <br><br>Of course, they have more than just sugar glazed doughnuts. They have many flavored doughnuts and even stuffed doughnuts. The chocolate ones are quite popular among my friends but I would say I prefer the dark chocolate ones because they are less sweet. Ok, let me say this for one last time, NO ONE RESISTS A DOUGHNUT FROM J.CO!

I love JCo donuts!! They are always very fresh tasting even late in the afternoon. My favorites are the tiramisu, banana, and Oreo. Get the full size donuts and skip the multi pack minis they aren&#39;t as yummy in smaller sizes. JCo lost a star for me because their coffee is just so so.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ucpO1bImBBweDJB9nSfZGw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/pru-cafe-singapore?reviewid=HtXLtVTmVhGQh6nAkDOsRw&select=ucpO1bImBBweDJB9nSfZGw', 'altText': 'Photo of Pru Cafe - Singapore, Singapore. Hacks, anyone?', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Hacks, anyone?'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/9hY5sEf6dV2A_HOiSGfirQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/pru-cafe-singapore?reviewid=HtXLtVTmVhGQh6nAkDOsRw&select=9hY5sEf6dV2A_HOiSGfirQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Pru Cafe - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: This place caters mostly to the people working in Prudential Building and the environs. <br><br>The cafe sells basic food and drinks like local coffee, tea, milo as well as canned drinks (soda and fruit juice) and milk. Fresh cut fruits are also available, as are steamed buns, curry puffs and some nonya kuehs. <br><br>For the heavier breakfast items, prepacked boxes of noodles (regular and vegetarian), nasi lemak, fried carrot cake and peanut minced meat porridge (add 50c for century egg) will be for sale too. <br><br>Lunch time is the most crowded with many people getting food to go or for dining in. Again, the lunch items are also prepacked containers of food which are delivered to the cafe close to 12 noon. It will usually be sold out in 30 minutes or so, or the selection will be limited if you get there around 1pm. <br><br>Lunch dishes include favorites like wanton noodles, fishball noodles, minced meat noodles, rice with braised pork belly and mei cai (preserved vegetables), rice with chicken and mushroom, xin zhou bee hoon, char kway teow, hokkien mee, etc. Typical Singaporean food. <br><br>Oh and you could also buy chips and sweets (Hacks, anyone?).

A small, very local mom and pop cafe next to Goldbell and inside the Prudential Center that mostly served as a lunch spot for me when I was short on time.<br><br>A small tip to venture in quickly before noon to avoid the typical lunch crowd and long lines- after 1pm and chances of anything being left or catering to your palette was slim. <br><br>Nothing prepared fresh at the time- everything is prepacked in styrofoam or plastic containers. My go to was the fried rice with chicken. They also have noodle options that were a little on the bland/hard side, but the rice was always a safe bet. The iced coffee is also delicious.<br><br>Again, nothing to write home about, this was always a last minute resort kind of place for me, but on the plus side it&#39;s relatively inexpensive.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ZSE_pJqb_GZZRmRctdz7jA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/starbucks-singapore-93?reviewid=2g1pSls05K1V8Isw5s35Uw&select=ZSE_pJqb_GZZRmRctdz7jA', 'altText': 'Photo of Starbucks - Singapore, Singapore. Storefront for Starbucks City Square Mall', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Storefront for Starbucks City Square Mall'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/vg2t2SY0xQOK-wM_V_zlLQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/starbucks-singapore-93?reviewid=2g1pSls05K1V8Isw5s35Uw&select=vg2t2SY0xQOK-wM_V_zlLQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Starbucks - Singapore, Singapore. Seating Area at Starbucks City Square Mall', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Seating Area at Starbucks City Square Mall'}]
text: This is a decent Starbucks well located in the City Square Mall. The service is good and the prices are about what you would expect. The only drawback is the that the seating area is not particularly sizeable given the brisk foot traffic at the Mall and it gets a bit crowded. There is outdoor seating but that is only so appealing in Singapore. The counter area also tends to be a bit tight on space. However, the coffee creations certainly are up to par. If you are a Starbucks fan and need a coffee, this location works well for that purpose.

text: Sort of like a Books Actually for the Chinese set. I chanced upon this place while waiting for my resuscitation course to start next door.<br><br>Floor-to-ceiling bookshelves with plenty of indie-looking Chinese publications. They also had a some English children&#39;s books at a table in the middle (but the mix was 85% Chinese, 15% English). There&#39;s a small cafe/sitting area at the back of the shop for you to enjoy your book and a drink. You have to pay for the book first before entering though.<br><br>I liked the vibe of this place. It almost made me want to start reading a Chinese book... Almost.

text: Great bookshop -- you can see Yeng Pway Ngon&#39;s taste in books on the shelves. The books in the cafe area are also for sale and obviously from the original Grassroots Book Room collection that local writer Yeng was in charge of for 20 years. <br><br>Tasteful, not too hipstery, and simple cafe. Could do with a few more food options, which is the only reason why this is a four-star vote. It&#39;s mainly a coffee and tea place right now.<br><br>It could have bigger and bolder signage too. See, I&#39;m literate so I read signs, but two tourists walked in, took a look, and declared, &#34;No food!&#34; and left the bookstore and cafe EVEN THOUGH THERE WERE LOAVES OF BREAD AND PASTRIES ON DISPLAY.<br><br>I think these days advertising really needs to be in-your-face to succeed, not subtle. A pity.<br><br>I will be back! Even though I am not great at Chinese.

You can really feel a connection with the staff here, you enter a cosy and warm cafe that serves excellent food and drinks.<br>Pros: Books, pool table, cigars and great whisky. <br>Cons: Not closer to my home

We visited this place because we read about their Truffles promotion. The decor certainly is very impressive with books neatly arranged from wall to wall and old phones decorated at various locations. The ambience is great for catch up with friends over a drink. <br><br>We&#39;ve ordered our main courses all from the promo menu and truffle Parmesan fries. It took close to 20 mins before the fries arrived followed by pasta and burger. The Pork neck grill took another 10 mins to be delivered. Sadly, the burger and the Pork neck was more salty than needed while the pasta is blend. We are more sad that with all the truffle shavings on the pasta and pork neck, we can&#39;t smell the truffles. Which is very unusual as this is not the first time we&#39;ve had truffle dishes. <br><br>Even with the promotion, each dish is about $28. And for that price, I don&#39;t see the value when I have the 3 small pieces of pork neck done like schnitzels, topped with creamy sauce and potato chips that occupied half of the plate. We couldn&#39;t finish our food because I get tired chewing the pork neck and the pasta was too blend to warrant anymore consumption. The saving grace is the burger because it&#39;s not too big and, the parmesan fries has a very nice truffle mayo dip. <br><br>I really want this place to work out better for customers because they are in a very nice location and the decor is great! <br><br>I re

Lots of books and games for your use', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Lots of books and games for your use'}]
text: We were on our way to another cafe but spotted The Reading Room enroute. The charming facade looks cozy and enticed us to make a quick stop to view the place.<br><br>We ended up staying for an hour and a half!<br><br>Very cozy atmosphere with unique, vintage-like decoration. The coffee was average in quality but the atmosphere was the pull factor for us to return the next time.<br><br>Book lovers will rejoice as the place is a good, quiet hide-out from the busy world to have a cuppa and to have a good reading session. For those who want a place to chill out with friends and catch-up, there&#39;s a bigger seating area at the back for big groups. Board games and card games are also available and placed discreetly on the bookshelves - the trick is to be the first to find them!<br><br>Will definitely recommend this place to friends.

Matcha latte', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Matcha latte'}]
text: The Reading Room is really an interesting quirky cafe for some good drinks &amp; reading time. We visited this cafe for a Sunday brunch after making a reservation, although the reservation was not a necessity! The moment you step inside the cafe, all the books arranged give you a very good vibe &amp; make you feel you are in a library. They have lot of books of varied interests. We saw some of them even working on laptops or reading books for hours. The staff is really very friendly. One cannot visit this place with less time as it&#39;s a laid back cafe vibe with slow service. We ordered Eggs Benedict with portobello &amp; Parmesan crisps and Smashed Avocado with Smoked salmon with Matcha latte &amp; orange juice. While Matcha &amp; juice was tasty &amp; fresh, the food was bland. The food was very mediocre, no taste but it was fresh. This restaurant can be a gem only with better food service, hence did not deserve the 5 star. Overall it&#39;s an amazing place to read some books over coffee/tea with no time constraint!

text: coffee, restaurant and tapas bar near outram MRT<br><br>the bookshelves  which decorates the place  gives a very pleasant and imitate atmosphere.<br>There is another room just besides used for event.<br><br>Food : 3/5<br>We had some tapas and Burger to share<br>The tapas are nice, a bit small.<br>I had better burger<br><br>Service : 4/5<br>Nice people and owner is really cool<br><br>Value : 3/5<br>A bit pricy for the place.<br><br>Atmosphere : 4/5<br>Tables are too small for dinner.<br>Not very convenient <br>It is a better coffee place than a restaurant

This is by far one of the most interesting places I&#39;ve seen in Singapore... Set up to look like a library, The Reading Room has a varied selection of books to read (and to purchase) while being a full functioning café. I only went for afternoon drinks and was delightfully surprised by very nice happy hour offerings, on glasses of red and white wine as well as on beers, and other drinks. It did look like it had a nice brunch menu, and their burger offerings for dinner looked quite nice. At around 6:30 PM however, they shut off most of the lights, which I think was a real mood killer. No need to have lighting resembling that of a sketchy club, when you are in a nice café where people want to go to talk each other, and in fact, see each other too.

text: Delicious tapas amidst lush greenery.<br><br>I&#39;m a little surprised about the low rating for this place. My friend and I went there for dinner last night and we were quite satisfied with the experience.<br><br>We didn&#39;t have a reservation but the host was kind enough to offer to wipe down the table (it was pouring earlier) and seat us outside. They had mosquito coil under the table which I thought was a nice gesture, I was still bitten once but that&#39;s not too bad..<br><br>I love the fact that the menu is not too big and the waiters seem knowledgable about the food. Quick individual reviews: Cod (extremely delicious and was our favorite, perfectly cooked; the mushroom and spinach and broth complement the fish well), cauliflower (tender inside with a slight crunch on the outside), lamb ribs (must try, very interesting spices), bone marrow (i&#39;ve never had bone marrow with snails but good combination), strawberry basil sangria (a little too sweet, would have been perfect for brunch).<br><br>Minus: Slow service. Price is probably average for Dempsey Hill :)

text: The Disgruntled Chef (TDC) has got to be one of my favorite restaurants here in the glitzy neighborhood that is Demsey Hill. Ever since my first visit back in 2012, I&#39;ve revisited a couple of times may it be for a quick bite or just a couple of after-work drinks with my colleagues. <br><br>Two Sundays ago, me and 2 other friends decided to visit the restaurant for a casual brunch and to try out some new items in their brunch &#34;tartines&#34; menu. We reached at around 12-ish and were greeted by the manager in charge, Max. The restaurant recently underwent some minor &#34;face lifts&#34; with nicely upholstered chair and the addition of 2 very modern / zen centerpiece. But what makes this place so inviting anytime of the day is the beautiful natural light that shines through the glass panels from one side of the restaurant. The other side of the restaurant faces the &#34;jungle&#34; gives it a cooling and relaxing effect while you dine in.<br><br>For drinks, M and S ordered mocktails each while I opted for a cocktail (of course.. by any given chance to get drunk on a Sunday) . Their mocktails were refreshingly while my sea salt and chili margarita totally woke me up from my half-sleepy state. Not too strong but still with a kick. Love the Ron Julio Reposado tequila they use as the base. <br><br>We had seared scallop Carpaccio and beet-cured king salmon for starters. The bright color of the king salmon (from the beet) got us asking for more while we polished that plate of scallop carpaccio within minutes. Both starters were light, flavourful and perfect start to the afternoon.  For mains, we had a plate of crackling suckling pig and grilled french quail to share.  While we all agree that the mains should be bigger in portion, the flavors were spot on and the accompaniment definitely elevated the dish. The suckling pig was amazingly good with mashed sauerkraut and mustard while the grilled quail comes with bits of bacon sprinkled all over it. <br><br>From the newly brunch tartines menu, we tried 2 items - one savoury and one sweet. For savoury, we had braised whole egg plant with onion, garlic and tomatoes with pine nuts. I might be slightly biased and you can just grill an eggplant with salt and I would say it&#39;s good. This one was phenomenal. For sweet, we had a bostock brioche with almond cream paired with prune and almagnac ice cream. Typing the description itself makes me really hungry now. FML.  And if you&#39;re here, this is something I would highly recommend you order.<br><br>For desserts, we felt that the poached pear was slightly undercook (hard) and could be executed better. I am not a big fan of poached pear so I just had a small piece and washed down with the lemongrass tea I ordered. My dining partner had a latte and was impressed to know they brew Vittoria coffee from Australia.  <br><br>Service was attentive and our glasses were filled with water most if not throughout the meal.

text: We visited on a Friday afternoon, one of the few restaurants on Dempsey that could accommodate us without reservations. I got the set lunch, consisting of a salad/soup, main and dessert, for $38++. It was decent though not fantastic, main gripe though, was that the service was achingly slow. <br><br>- Roasted pumpkin salad with Roquefort cheese: more pumpkin than rocket, and it was slathered in a heavy glaze. It was a bit heavy tasting, though the pumpkin went well with the cheese. <br><br>- Grilled Norwegian salmon, chorizo and shaved fennel: presentation was good and the diced chorizo in beans was tasty. While the salmon skin was nice and crispy, the fish was slightly overcooked, tough and bland. <br><br>- Sweet corn panna cotta, popcorn and truffle oil: slightly too firm but went nicely with the popcorn. The truffle undertone definitely added an interesting twist to the dish. <br><br>I also heard good things about the hangar steak and prawn linguine that my friends opted for. <br><br>Seems like the dinner items seem better than the lunch. Would love to return to try!

text: This was a nice quiet dining experience.  When we arrived, I was surprised to find the restaurant nearly empty.  i know it was a Tuesday night.  But I had expected it to be slightly busier.  <br><br>The room is modern, sleek, and comfortable.  The service was timely, polite, and professional.  The meal was paced well.<br><br>The menu is divided into small plates and large plates.  We decided on four small plates and two large plates.<br><br>The food ranged from relatively good to very good.  <br><br>I will review the dishes in the order they came out.<br><br>Serrano Ham with marinated melon - This was a very nice dish.  I actually did not think the fruit was melon.  But, it was sweet and made a perfect contrast with the saltiness of the Serrano ham.  I would order this dish again in a flash.<br><br><a href="/redir?url=http%3A%2F%2Ftinyurl.com%2F93rknel&amp;s=0601af2aa0b179160ee42df71147b658936a58a434dc4a7dd4abe1ca9dd5a22b" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">tinyurl.com/93rknel</a><br><br>Crispy Lamb Short-Ribs - From a taste perspective, I enjoyed these.  I also thought they went well paired with the ham that was served at the same time.  However, from a texture standpoint, they were very dry.<br><br><a href="/redir?url=http%3A%2F%2Ftinyurl.com%2F9fmn448&amp;s=949b09e8ac9d35df57ff69b0a2423aefc327f7f08528496e08afb83206254d41" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">tinyurl.com/9fmn448</a><br><br>Scallops - The scallops themselves were pretty good. But there was simply too much olive oil in the sauce.  The flavor of the olive oil overpowered many of the other flavors.  The small tomatoes were some of the best I&#39;ve eaten in Singapore.<br><br><a href="/redir?url=http%3A%2F%2Ftinyurl.com%2F8sphepw&amp;s=35b9fe2da5b1650e9c386142d05bbb0b787975fa96019911c38a7d0e0cc51f37" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">tinyurl.com/8sphepw</a><br><br>King Prawns al la Plancha - The prawns were good but certainly not the best I&#39;ve had recently.  The mushroom and chorizo ragout was very nice.  I enjoyed this more than the prawns themselves.  I would note that the two elements of this dish (prawns and ragout) did not really marry as a dish.  It was more like two distinct dishes.<br><br><a href="/redir?url=http%3A%2F%2Ftinyurl.com%2F8uf7m6t&amp;s=b0024862327b15921430b01c7219fbb7d7b79c1764688e55d8dd938415e73b5a" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">tinyurl.com/8uf7m6t</a><br><br>Steamed Mussels - We loved these.  Lol, my companion wrestled the dish back from a server to insure she could have the very last mussel.  They were quite small.  But they were very tender and the citrus flavors of the broth were very refreshing.<br><br><a href="/redir?url=http%3A%2F%2Ftinyurl.com%2F98qmkp7&amp;s=4cba5e748c6b053558b4bfb97dde4367d4154b3d5a9e40e44d95f88c4c413abf" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">tinyurl.com/98qmkp7</a><br><br>Roaster Miso Cod - This was a nice dish.  There wasn&#39;t anything particularly fancy about it.  But the fish was well prepared and the flavors were very delicate.<br><br><a href="/redir?url=http%3A%2F%2Ftinyurl.com%2F8swr5hw&amp;s=9e8b312906241df885581e8c5278c9d32a27e97a478e6c8c25858d87835654c0" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">tinyurl.com/8swr5hw</a><br><br>Apple Rhubarb Crumble - For dessert, I selected the crumble.  This was very much a western style comfort dessert.  The crumble part was a little harder than a normal crumble.  This made it difficult to incorporate both crumble and fruit into single bites.  But the rhubarb and apples worked perfectly together.  I enjoyed this every much.<br><br><a href="/redir?url=http%3A%2F%2Ftinyurl.com%2F8ldncv9&amp;s=b492bbd8b4596e23ecb5696789a2496791dd352f1817526593ec6087e9bdbe90" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">tinyurl.com/8ldncv9</a><br><br>Passion Fruit Brûlée Cocktail - My friend selected a cocktail for dessert.  It looked quite tasty and she certainly seemed to enjoy it.  <br><br><a href="/redir?url=http%3A%2F%2Ftinyurl.com%2F8knxyo9&amp;s=fd38972ce159066404bce8da21531d0e279f06051f17441beb844dca5f2721fe" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">tinyurl.com/8knxyo9</a><br><br>Overall, this was a very enjoyable dining experience.  While not extraordinary, the restaurant does combine a very nice ambiance, solid service, and, for the most part, well executed and presented food.  I would return.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/gy4t3i8DhJpXFpbGUoD2mA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-disgruntled-chef-singapore?reviewid=tpaowVrN5l_8tFlQnLeKiQ&select=gy4t3i8DhJpXFpbGUoD2mA', 'altText': 'Photo of The Disgruntled Chef - Singapore, Singapore. posh magnum: roquefort ice cream in a dark chocolate shell', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'posh magnum: roquefort ice cream in a dark chocolate shell'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/bhhc0pqwYPwGSgcgB16pJA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-disgruntled-chef-singapore?reviewid=tpaowVrN5l_8tFlQnLeKiQ&select=bhhc0pqwYPwGSgcgB16pJA', 'altText': 'Photo of The Disgruntled Chef - Singapore, Singapore. braised pork cheeks', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'braised pork cheeks'}]
text: I was rather disappointed by this place. I went with high hopes, bolstered by a slew of wonderful praises about the ingenuity of the food here, and the suspense was ever-more built by the fact that I had tried to brunch here more than a couple times (and something always happened to stop it*).<br><br>*maybe it was the gourmand gods/ fate.<br><br>it&#39;s a rather awesome menu - large, interesting-sounding, and immensely enticing what with the descriptions. I massively love menus that tell me exactly what I&#39;m going to eat - there&#39;s something to be said for being held in suspense, but usually I like to order what I know I&#39;d really want to eat.<br><br>I&#39;ve come to a point where small portions are appreciated only when expected - usually as part of a many-coursed meal - and I most certainly don&#39;t expect it at brunch, which in itself is a hedonistic activity to ingest in a single meal what you would eat in two.<br><br>the amount of food we got irked me to no end, especially since the quality of cooking and execution here was pretty great. it&#39;s a pretty refined brunch, dishes are colorful, and the flavors are more than decent.<br><br>an eggs cocotte was redolent with truffle and savoury mushrooms, and my halloumi dish was perked up with segments of peeled orange and a couple gren leaves.<br><br>the partner was the only one that ordered a brunch big of braised pork cheeks, all soft and tender and delicious over a bed of soft silky truffled mash.<br><br>but at twenty for my halloumi, I expect a little more than what would constitute only a small square of cheese and not even half an orange; and at thirty for the pork cheeks, perhaps some greens would have been welcome - not to mention quite a bit more mash or meat for a satisfying meal.<br><br>the desserts were even more spectacular in execution, but didn&#39;t buck the (lack of) size trend.<br><br>this magnum-like bar of roquefort &amp; honey ice cream coated in dark chocolate was a play on contrast between the rather blue ice cream and the not-too-sweet quality chocolate shell that shattered upon impact. I can&#39;t much tolerate blue cheeses, and this was almost too strong for me to take, but the chocolate helped temper the pungency - and I found myself returning for more.<br><br>the sticky toffee pudding was also darn delicious (and more sizable!): warm, moist pud sloping with its weight of delicious vanilla-speckled ice cream all drizzled with a delicious caramel.<br><br>and also the peanut-butter-and-chocolate fondant, which came super dark (almost black, really) with roast banana slices on the side with another scoop of that fantastic icecream. it was warm and oozey and satisfyingly chocolatey.<br><br>at the end of it, it was a fantastic meal flavor-wise. the chefs know what they&#39;re doing in the kitchen, and flavors are contrasting and complementary, and the plating is both beautiful and very modern - but with three courses needed for any measure of satiety, and lunch-set portions what&#39;s more, it&#39;s a format of dining I think best left for more measured, formal meals than brunch.<br><br>the meal left me disgruntled for sure - I understand restaurants need to be profitable, but there&#39;s a fine line between sustainability and miserliness, and I think they might have stepped over it.

This swish little restaurant, tucked away in the Dempsey Hill area is a nice spot for something a tad upmarket. <br><br>For dinner and during the week, I&#39;m sure it&#39;s pumping with work catch ups, dates and small groups working their way through the menu.<br><br>We came here on a Sunday afternoon and it was very quiet, just one other table in the venue (also Australians, seems to be popular with expats) and a limited brunch menu. <br><br>On weekends, the menu is limited to brunch tartines (open sandwich) and a couple of specials only. We opted for the lobster tartine - definitely as fancy as it sounds. One big slab of bread covered in delicious lobster and toasted gruyere. We also opted for the special, which was truffled chicken. Also delicious and delicately portioned. <br><br>The food is expensive, but the ingredients are high quality too. I did scoff at the $20+ &#39;Melbourne tartine&#39; of smashed avocado on toast, but then again they charge about $18 for fancy versions of that at home too. <br><br>The service was very attentive (almost too much given how few people were there) and it was a relaxing and quiet break after a full week of living on hawker centre food.

Suckling pig', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Suckling pig'}]
text: Hits &amp; misses. Adventurous tapas with a local spin...<br><br>Fusion or confusion is always a fine line.<br><br>The first time I went, I like it better. The second time, not so good. So not sure when there will be a third time. The famed suckling pig tasted too &#34;porky&#34; the second visit.<br><br>What I like most is the space and the location. Wonderfully isolated, with a cool chic decor.

text: We were really excited when we heard that Daniel Sia had opened up his own restaurant and went to check it out as soon as we could.<br><br>We ordered the crabcakes with tomato chilli jam, baked sea scallops, baked bone marrow with sour dough toast and the crayfish mac n cheese.<br><br>They were all OK but not as good as we had hoped.

Pulled Pork Sliders', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Pulled Pork Sliders'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/cUePXVaGdKOzA6fQ9l3f4w/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-disgruntled-chef-singapore?reviewid=YB8qHCVlwOm-YhZngOxX2A&select=cUePXVaGdKOzA6fQ9l3f4w', 'altText': 'Photo of The Disgruntled Chef - Singapore, Singapore. Crackling Suckling Pig', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Crackling Suckling Pig'}]
text: Tucked away in a quiet corner, the Disgruntled Chef at 26B is one of the newer additions to Dempsey Hill. <br><br>Award winning chef Daniel Sia has cooked up exciting modern European dishes. However, on a balance, we felt that this was not something mindblowing, and the waiters were rather inexperienced and mixed our still water with tap water however they were extremely apologetic about it. <br><br>The nibblets were surprisingly good. As we waited for our friends to arrived, we tried some siders - pulled pork sandwich ($3.50 each) and was amazed by the texture, taste and quality of this mini burger. Salf of the sea ($8) - which is essentially fried fish skin and chips was pretty good too. <br><br>What could be improved: The tartine of anchovy ($5 each) which was served on a piece of toast was a little too salty for our liking. Also, the crab cakes ($5 each) was a tad too spicy, and with such a small portion only just fitting a table spoon, it&#39;s hardly satisfying. <br><br>For starters, we had the Eel and Foie Gras ($26) which was one of my favourites of the night as it had a perfect mix of sweet and savoury. Dripped with delicious sweet sauce (Kabayaki sauce), the foie gras was wrapped in the eel and served with a piece of cut nashi pear and apple chips to top it off. Also on my favourite list is the steak tatare with soft quail egg ($18) in the middle that added a dash of flavour, but all in all it much tasted like nigiri. <br><br>Worth a mention is their drinks. The Bloody Mary ($16) which was bloody good. It had the right amount of tobasco sauce, and was extremely refreshing. <br><br>For mains, I had the crackling suckling pig ($68) which was a really small portion of meat served with some pickled cucumber marinated with honey and clove sauce for sides. Taste-wise, it is comparable to the suckling pigs you get in traditional Chinese restaurants like Imperial Treasure. However, portion-wise, it may not even be sufficient to fill the stomach of one person.

I&#39;m actually quite a big fan of The Disgruntled Chef. <br><br>For one thing, the dishes are generally interesting, and while some may be more miss than hit, there are some dishes absolutely TO-DIE-FOR. Do note though that they recently changed their menu, so some of the items previous Yelpers mentioned might no longer be available.<br><br>Before I get into the food, I do like their sangrias, and don&#39;t like their brunch menu, so really, best time to go? Dinner, or weekday lunches where they have great value sets.<br><br>Okay. Ribs. Crispy lamb shortribs. OMG THESE ARE LIKE CRACK. They&#39;re crispy, fall off the bone tender and flavourful, served with a yoghurt sauce and couscous. It&#39;s just the bomb. I could work through a plate of these allll byyyyy myyyyyself. (Yes you&#39;re supposed to imagine me sing that)<br><br>The fish skin. Deep fried. Crisp. Light. Super appetizing. If you&#39;ve never tried fried fish skin, you need to try it. Think pork cracking, but well. With a SLIGHT fish taste. I believe the dish was called salt of the sea or something like that.<br><br>Beyond that? Many of the other dishes are pretty good, though those two are by far the absolute bests on the menu imho. <br><br>I&#39;ve been with 3-4 different groups of people, so trust me when I say it&#39;s generally a hit amongst most people I introduce to it.<br><br>The biggest compliment I would pay it though, is that I personally think a meal at TDC is far more worth it than Bacchanalia. Similar concept, in the sharing dishes and modernity. Totally different pricing, totally different feels... but for me TDC is so much better value, and so much more likeable. #truestorybrah

My better half dined here for lunch and felt it was reasonable as they offered a set menu. We had a hankering so decided to go to the Disgruntled Chef for dinner.<br><br>Our server let us know the cuisine was modern European, tapas style and we were encouraged to share. So with that, we were off to explore and sample. Service was attentive and prompt, with helpful recommendations. The menu had nibbles, small plates and big plates. There were also sides but we were already mired in the decisions on the other 3, adding another category would only confuse us further. The waiter was helpful and suggested 5-6 small plates, or 1 big with some smalls. We ordered the following:<br><br>Nibbles<br>Salt of the Sea (Crispy fish skin &amp; potato chips)<br>I liked this dish a lot. Fish skin had the right crackle and got us off to a great start. Served with a vinegar sauce that enhanced the dish. Portions were substantial. Unfortunately, that couldn&#39;t be said about the chips. They were so drenched in oil and were soft and chewy. A bag of Lay&#39;s would&#39;ve been fresher.<br><br>Serrano Ham Bikini sandwiches with Brie<br>I get the fancy, descriptive premium ingredients but when it looks smaller than my morning kaya toast, it just doesn&#39;t cut it. In Catalan Spain, grilled cheese sandwiches are named bikinis. Sadly I was thinking of the diet sized portion of this dish so that one can fit into that piece of swimwear. It is so small, I don&#39;t think it should be served even as a nibble. It was dark and I didn&#39;t want to do any more injustice than needed by accompanying this review with dimly lit, poor shots of our meal.<br><br>Small plates<br>Crispy Lamb Shortribs with Chilli &amp; Cumin<br>This dish was lovely. Shortribs melted in your mouth. Lovely hint of spices. I almost didn&#39;t want to share.<br><br>Momotaro Tomatoes with Arugula &amp; Miso-Burnt Butter Dressing<br>4 slices of soft, over-ripened tomatoes. Maybe the vinegar from the crispy fish skin had overpowered our taste buds but the dressing didn&#39;t come out. 4 slices?! It just barely qualifies as a whole tomato in my books.<br><br>Big plate<br>Fideua Negra (thin squid ink noodles with grilled squid, mussels &amp; prawns)<br>I found this dish almost.... there. You are served in the plate that the whole dish is baked in. The black squid ink noodles give a sweetness and very interesting taste. Lovely, but unfortunately what marred the dish were the very overcooked prawns that became pasty. Additionally for the price, the amount of seafood is underwhelming. <br><br>Dessert<br>Lemon Tart with Creme Fraiche &amp; Blueberry Compote<br><br>I wanted to like this place more. Cool name for a restaurant, vibe is upbeat, and it looked like a place to hangout in the alfresco area. The menu was tantalizing with lots of dishes that we wanted to try. Unfortunately the food and the dining experience we had overall was average. There were more misses that hits and we walked away feeling that for the price points they were charging, there are better options in this city. Huge potential, fails to deliver.

text: We visited on a Saturday night and the place was surprisingly not busy.  Food was not the usual Asian fare in Dempsey and was actually a nice change.  Had their version of bone marrow, scallops and duck confit.  All worthy efforts and if you need a change from the usual local style of food.  We do feel the restaurant lacked any real ambiance and in fact felt sterile.  It has a trendier feel, perhaps a bit out of place here, but worth a visit for their unique menu items.  Like most places in Dempsey, expensive.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=bHfBMb8ABQpmSR1wzzZAFw', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/assets/srv0/yelp_styleguide/514f6997a318/assets/img/default_avatars/user_60_square.png', 'srcSet': None, 'markupDisplayName': 'MJ B.', 'displayLocation': 'Hoboken, NJ', 'altText': 'MJ B.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=bHfBMb8ABQpmSR1wzzZAFw', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 1, 'photoCount': 2, 'reviewCount': 162, 'eliteYear': None}
text: It was a late Sunday lunch and intended to go to PS Cafe at Dempsey Hill. It was a 1.5 hour wait so we walked out and went to the next restaurant which was The Disgruntled Chef. We are all pleasantly surprised as the food was quite good. For the appetizer, I had the crispy lamb shortribs which had like a mediterranean rub. It was very tasty and cooked perfectly -- tender and juicy. For the main, I had the Roasted Miso Cod with mushrooms and baby spinach and it was fantastic. The flavor of the mushrooms and spinach did not over power the cod. The cod was perfectly cooked which was bursting with flavor. The winner was the dessert -- Roquefort Magnum --- roquefort and honey ice cream coated in dark chocolate. Don&#39;t be deceived as it is looks like your grocery ice cream served in a bowl of ice. But take a bite and its a blue cheese flavored ice cream with the right balance of sweetness from the honey and dark chocolate. Perfect ending to a meal!<br>The only down side are -- first, the menu is not so clear &#34;Brunch Smalls&#34; and &#34;Brunch Bigs&#34;, who would have known it meant appetizers and mains? Second, the servers are not familiar with the menu so its quite frustrating if you want to know more about a dish. Lastly, the service is very slow. We didn&#39;t notice it so much since I was dining with friends whom I have not seen so we were catching up. But we did notice that it took them 45mins to serve our dessert.

text: really good fusion tapas.  i know tapas is quite trendy in SG now, but this place is actually quite good.  my comparison is both local SG tapas places, as well as San Francisco tapas restaurants.

text: a hole in the wall along the five foot way.<br><br>was craving for some dessert after eating at mooi chin.<br>spotted their spanking new, clean and well lit unit from across the road and it seemed like a god send.<br><br>coffee from $2.30 and homemade gelato from $2.90.<br>but affogato for $3.90??? i&#39;m sold and it was good!<br>the espresso was strong and i chose the creamy, nutty hazelnut gelato to pair with it.<br>was advised not to mix it up too much, so as to fully enjoy the espresso.<br><br>could not help but ask them what gofre meant.<br>was told it is a type of waffle.<br>yes, they do handheld waffle with gelato at $5.80.<br><br>a high ceiling fan keeps gofre cool on hot days and stuffy nights.<br><br>limited flavours and quantity of gelato for now.<br>limited seating in the form of 2 bar tables and high stools.

Katsu and beef curry ;)', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Katsu and beef curry ;)'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/L6Okl-W5u_3oYRluB6Zdrg/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/kotobuki-coffee-singapore-2?reviewid=gQB_AdJAjXJdPIWpKon2aQ&select=L6Okl-W5u_3oYRluB6Zdrg', 'altText': 'Photo of Kotobuki Coffee - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}]
text: The first time I was here on a weekday during lunch hour, my eyes were glued on the katsu and curry don (on the lunch menu) so I decided to try it out.<br><br>The food was served within 15 minutes of waiting. The katsu was cooled down when served. Texture wise, it is as crunchy and tender as it looks but would prefer it to be served warmer. The curry had potatoes and beef in it and as I was pouring on my don (rice), it still had the steaming effect. For the lunch set, it will come with salad and a small slice of watermelon. For this dish, I would gladly give a 4 stars.<br><br>The second time visiting this place was on a Saturday during tea break (around 2pm). Decided to give the Yuzu Snow cake a try. The Yuzu was strong and the jelly square bits on the top made it more chewy. According to my friend, it was refreshing.<br><br>I also managed to take a spoonful of my friend&#39;s matcha cake. There were too much cream in the middle that the taste of matcha was rather mild. It was soft and light. But for a friend with little tolerance of sweet desserts, she claimed that it was just right for her tastebuds.<br><br>Ambience here is pretty cosy. Depending on the crowd, you can chose an indoor or outdoor (open space) seatings. I prefer the outdoor seating as you can see how they drip the coffees too and also good spot to observe people.<br><br>Price wise, I think it is on the pricier end. But I did enjoy my dish that I got on the first visit. Will drop by to fulfill my curry and katsu cravings in the near future :)

Can&#39;t believe there isn&#39;t an entry for Coffee Bean. It&#39;s been a year since they opened I guess.<br><br>Starbucks was the main coffee place at NEX that one can lounge in, but hooray there&#39;s now coffee bean too!<br><br>The seating area is kinda limited though as it is situated at level 2, nestled along one of the walkways. It can be hard to get a seat during peak hours but it&#39;s still definitely much easier to snag a seat then the perpetually-crowded Starbucks!<br><br>Love, love, love their pasta, though I think that it increased price in recent years! Try their vegetarian tomato herb pasta; simple, delicious and wholesome!

Not too big outlet but seating arrangements are spacious. Only thing I find weird is there are no power points for people to charge their mobile devices. This can be good though... Less table hogging? During normal days, the outlet should be pretty good for small chats and get-together. I would come here for a &#34;switch off my mind over a coffee&#34; day anytime.

text: Accidentally picked up wrong mobile order drink n the barista lectured me like I&#39;m idiot for not recognising my own drink size. When he called out the order he announced &#34;for mobile order&#34; instead of calling out by name like every other barista I ordered from. Besides, before I picked up I turned the cup several times to try to check the mobile order sticker, yet it was pasted inside with the cup handler put over n covering it, for who to read? Every other barista I ordered from pastes it outside the handler so it is clear. C&#39;mon mr barista, ur customers don&#39;t work at Starbucks, we r not going to instantly recognise cup size jus by looking at it, plz b more sensible n understanding

Gula Melaka cake with black coffee set and Dr Joe Signature 1914', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Gula Melaka cake with black coffee set and Dr Joe Signature 1914'}]
text: It&#39;s been a while since Joe &amp; Dough took over the Costa Coffee space at Plaza Singapura and yet, this is the first time that I am having coffee/cake at this outlet (all thanks to my daughter&#39;s chinese tuition class!).<br><br>The seating area is much more comfortable then Costa&#39;s set-up. Luckily for us, we were able to find quite a few good seats on an early Saturday Afternoon.<br><br>Definitely a cozy spot in the crowded shopping mall and will be back!

You have not been to Singapore if you haven&#39;t been on Geylang Road, and this terrace on the corner is a wonderful spot to eat (try the mie with sliced duck at 3 SGD!) and to view the hustle and bustle of shopping housewives, idling foreign workers in their dhotis, Chinese businessmen, whores and their pimps and passing taxis. This is not the nice and superclean Singapore, but it is very much alive!

text: You&#39;ll like this place if you are into tea. they have tea bags lining their counters and the drink i had a strong scent and taste of the oolong i ordered with a slight hint of peach.<br>i decided to  give it a try because they also offered cheese tea. sadly the cheese was lost in the tea and there was no hint of it other than the sight of it before i put my lips to the cup.

Singapore is the second country I&#39;ve visited where people describe to me what toast is and how it&#39;s created...a true testament to the reputation of American cuisine and intellect!<br><br>Anyway, I heard rumors of this amazing toast with kaya, and also another with peanut butter, and so that&#39;s what we ate for breakfast. Delicious, of course. A good coffee, and what else do you need? Nothing. <br><br>We were working, so an assistant got it as takeout...I didn&#39;t get the full Toastbox experience, but I got the best bits.

text: This place does a very good milo. Thick and sweet and not watered down milo like some other places. <br><br>The place can get quite crowded but at 9pm it is half filled. The place closes at 10pm and they will turn up the dimmer to brighten up the place. A subtle way to let customers know it is time to leave so that they can clean up and close shop. <br><br>Otherwise it is like any other Toastbox with the same drinks and food. <br><br>As it is next to the Food Republic and other restaurants under Breadtalk group, it is a convenient place to be for coffee or tea after a meal.

Toast Box... I Like. Doesn&#39;t that spells it all?', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': "Toast Box... I Like. Doesn't that spells it all?"}]
text: Yet another favorite haunt for my caffeine addiction. The coffee is full bodied and yet not too sweet. Coupled that with thick toast or Hebi Hiam Toast, its simply heaven for me. This place is generally crowded during working week but for weekend, I find it relaxing. There is indoors and outdoor seating compared to its usually small outfit in other malls. The outdoor is sheltered and has a high roof so you won&#39;t really feel the heat badly. So if you feel like a breather, head outdoors. But for me.. I still prefer the aircon la.

text: This place totally gets it when it comes to healthy breakfasts.  Would have given a 5th star if it was little bit less expensive. But then again, this is $ingapore!

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/q9y98l98sI_0z_Pu6xNkXg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/kitchen-by-food-rebel-singapore?reviewid=P001R6jMay0r9GWquK5SNA&select=q9y98l98sI_0z_Pu6xNkXg', 'altText': 'Photo of Kitchen by Food Rebel - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: I have never ever been so disappointed by lunch before.<br><br>I got the Superfood Salad, which was $18 ($19.80 after ++). See the picture attached with this review and decide for yourself if it&#39;s worth it. It&#39;s basically a tiny bed of tomato and lettuce mix with a teensy weensy bit of almond and walnut sprinkled. The dressing was tasty though.<br><br>The general consensus is that if this place was $5 less expensive, it would have been okay. But it&#39;s not.<br><br>I am typing this review in a queue for fish soup from a nearby hawker center because I felt like I haven&#39;t had lunch, even after paying $20.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ZRoADeza-tYlbBR2wqxCzw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/kitchen-by-food-rebel-singapore?reviewid=Ne5RABWoPF38-OShikkjfQ&select=ZRoADeza-tYlbBR2wqxCzw', 'altText': 'Photo of Kitchen by Food Rebel - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: Everything is pretty much gluten free. Good food but no ambiance. Great for quick breakfasts.

My work colleague always orders from Kitchen by Food Rebel and I&#39;ve been coveting her zoodle with meat sauce for weeks.  It&#39;s not far from our office, so we treked over there Friday for lunch.  First off, it&#39;s expensive, even for Singapore, and their margins are pretty insane.  I mean I had a zoodle (zucchini spiralized with meat sauce) and it was $18.   I&#39;m pretty sure a zucchini cost about $1.  The budda bowls looked pretty tasty, they also had some really good looking vegan desserts like carrot cake, an avocado mousse and brownie, but again all pretty steep on the price.  They serve breakfast and wine (not at the same time) and are a cute little place to go grab dinner with a friend or coworker, and the zoodle was good.  They do use quality ingredients, but for me it&#39;s still a bit steep.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=mufpQxFic_G2j_IqSDKbqQ', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/C046MJ5mbaqeig_S0wgHwA/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/C046MJ5mbaqeig_S0wgHwA/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/C046MJ5mbaqeig_S0wgHwA/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/C046MJ5mbaqeig_S0wgHwA/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/C046MJ5mbaqeig_S0wgHwA/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/C046MJ5mbaqeig_S0wgHwA/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Stephanie D.', 'displayLocation': 'Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Stephanie D.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=mufpQxFic_G2j_IqSDKbqQ', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 171, 'photoCount': None, 'reviewCount': 6, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Kitchen By Food Rebel is a cafe that makes clean eating delicious and filling! The food is delicious, healthy and creative - and I know where it has come from. The variety on the menu means there is something for everyone - if you want gluten free, dairy free, raw, organic, then you&#39;ve come to the right place. The staff are wonderfully friendly and welcoming. I would highly recommend the vegan buddha bowl, incredible hulk smoothie and the rebel pie.

text: Affordable, friendly helpful staff. I tried the roti prata with onion for breakfast 1.70 Delicious grab a coffee next door to go with it

Bait and switch?<br><br>A trip last week was disappointing. The ice cream melted off the scoop, it was practically liquid (and rapidly became actually liquid). Both sorbet and ice cream had little flavour, and somewhat synthetic. Both scoops were about half the usual size. Service was grumpy. <br><br>I really should go back and check that they have indeed shot quality, but such a bad experience - at the usual price - means I really do not want to. What a shame. Alfero was a giant.

text: Wonderful ambience for a Sunday morning brunch! Food was healthy and simple, yet elegantly prepared! Will definitely visit again!

Beverages', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Beverages'}]
text: Came here to enjoy a cup of coffee while waiting for my friend. The atmosphere is very cute and quiet. I really liked the atmosphere, and how spacious the cafe was. There&#39;s enough space between each table, so it didn&#39;t feel cramped at all. <br>The food menu items look good, but it seemed like it was on the pricey end. I ordered a flat white, which was $5.90. It was smaller than I expected, and it didn&#39;t scream &#34;great&#34; to me. It wasn&#39;t bad, but I&#39;m not sure if it&#39;s worth the price. However, if you want to cool down at a cafe with a nice atmosphere, this might be a nice cafe to stop by!

Salmon igloo', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Salmon igloo'}]
text: Pastas are great here. Portions are fairly large. Great atmosphere, enjoy sitting next to the windows. Their water is always infused and a refreshing treat in the heat.

text: Spacious with material interior design. Great menu but it&#39;s brand new so few people know the place yet. Visit before it gets too crowded.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/NPXyvDmTUfFoZftOQQP3_Q/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/froth-singapore?reviewid=l9IZApDUtQb-ylVKrfiQVQ&select=NPXyvDmTUfFoZftOQQP3_Q', 'altText': 'Photo of Froth - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: Froth at the Ascott serviced apartments has gained immensely in popularity since 2016. The spot is now packed out for lunch and for good reason - the food is mostly amazing. This is not a menu for calorie counters. The foie gras risotto will have you checking your cholesterol levels. The pastas are all on point as well. We&#39;ve tasted a few misses (lamb chops come to mind), but by and large, the plates are high quality. Service is slow, but steady - just don&#39;t expect a quick lunch and dash.

SioBak Aglio', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'SioBak Aglio'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/y1Sm2rcLEl-_VOF8Mgk-OA/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/froth-singapore?reviewid=lNUh_ncuTgPlMroaYqJKFg&select=y1Sm2rcLEl-_VOF8Mgk-OA', 'altText': 'Photo of Froth - Singapore, Singapore. Mango Tango &amp; Fruit Splash', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Mango Tango & Fruit Splash'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/4GZT9Hva798gOUlo0WCRcg/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/froth-singapore?reviewid=lNUh_ncuTgPlMroaYqJKFg&select=4GZT9Hva798gOUlo0WCRcg', 'altText': 'Photo of Froth - Singapore, Singapore. Squid Ink Lobster Burger', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Squid Ink Lobster Burger'}]
text: The cafe used to be located at the basement of Big Hotel before relocated to its current location. It took over the space formerly occupied by The Royal Mail which served British cuisine. Gone was the former old school dining decoration. It was replaced with a simple decoration. During the F1 weekend, the restaurant was having a 1-for-1 promotion for its items on the menu.<br><br>SioBak Aglio ($25.90++)<br>linguine served with homemade slow roasted pork belly crackling and pork jerky<br>The roast pork was yummy, light and crispy crust with juicy moist meat. But the pasta was a tab too oily.<br><br>Squid Ink Lobster Burger ($25.90++)<br>aburi lobster chunks, squid ink mentai mayo, nacho sauce, and tobiko on a charcoal bun<br>It was a huge black mess when served. The lobster was chunky although my partner remarked that it tasted frozen. I could not taste the nacho sauce in it.<br><br>Fruit Splash ($7.90++)<br>elderberries, raisins, papayas, apples, hibiscus, sunflowers, blackcurrants, cornflowers, raspberries, strawberries<br><br>Mango Tango ($7.90++)<br>green sencha tea, black ceylon tea, purple cornflowers, lemon myrtle, orange peel, mango pieces, natural flavouring<br><br>Both tea based drinks were disappointing. One cannot taste the tea flavour nor the fruits in the drinks. More like colored drinks.<br><br>Service was not bad. The place was fairly empty except for a big noisy group of 10 people.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/7uqDFFxh_wzaZdvjK1xTKg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/froth-singapore?reviewid=xQ0BD2mq8sibd2CBM5Lmkg&select=7uqDFFxh_wzaZdvjK1xTKg', 'altText': 'Photo of Froth - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: Had the hotel breakfast set<br><br>You can choose from choices<br><br>-congee<br>-LAKSA<br>-nasi lemak<br>-some yogurt muesli<br>-big breakfast<br>-omelette<br>-chicken sandwich set<br><br>Free flow of cereal, toast, fruits and coffee/tea.<br><br>Don&#39;t expect much but it kept my tummy full. Great ambience with high ceilings. I heard the lunch menu is pretty fab, there are some issues with higher prices but heck, I rather pay more for substantial food.

I love the concept at Froth, the menu items are interesting, and makes you want to try every one of them. The dishes, unfortunately, are a hit or miss. Some are really very good, like the seafood tom yum risotto, the slipper lobster sandwich and the waffles, especially with the salted caramel ice cream. The tom yum flavor blended surprisingly well with the creaminess of the risotto, and the generous portion of lobster with mentaiko was decadent and tasty. Others, just lack a little bit of flavor or oomph. The bacon chowder and seafood broth is chock full of flavor, but the consistency of the chowder is  a little chalky, and the sous vide salmon in the broth is a little too briny for my liking. The matcha rice with beef was disappointing, with meagre serving of beef which was too dry despite being one of the more expensive items on the menu ($30.90). The prawn aglio olio and carbonara lack flavor as a whole, and the sweet corn risotto was a tad too sweet, which was the same issue with the chilli crab spaghetti. 4 stars if you are wise with what you pick, 2 stars if you are not.

text: They serve all-day breakfast (mainly egg benedicts variations) and a few main courses. Menu is quite limited but from what we tried, they managed to do everything well. The pumpkin puree was a delight! Will definitely have it again. Service can be quite slow especially during peak hours, so be prepared to wait. Overall, good value for money!

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=hRMpQlJQDObCpNSJ1qd_fA', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/KBdaO8VXLPe1UqSkzRUNgA/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/KBdaO8VXLPe1UqSkzRUNgA/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/KBdaO8VXLPe1UqSkzRUNgA/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/KBdaO8VXLPe1UqSkzRUNgA/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/KBdaO8VXLPe1UqSkzRUNgA/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/KBdaO8VXLPe1UqSkzRUNgA/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Ricky S.', 'displayLocation': 'San Francisco, CA', 'altText': 'Ricky S.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=hRMpQlJQDObCpNSJ1qd_fA', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 77, 'photoCount': 537, 'reviewCount': 393, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Caught the Friday night comic showdown at The Basement Cafe. <br><br>The venue is located in the basement of the big SMU building (Singapore Management University). I did not know this when looking for the place so it took me a while to find it.<br><br>TIP: Follow the signs toward School of Information Management in the basement level and you&#39;ll find The Basement. Also, there was some construction on this end of the building which made it harder to find.<br><br>The venue itself is pretty standard fare, nothing special about it. They have assorted tables and chairs and benches throughout the large space with a stage in one corner. They have a HUGE column smack in the middle of the venue so if you&#39;re sitting behind said column, good luck making out what&#39;s going on on-stage.<br><br>Apparently they serve food and drinks here but didn&#39;t partake in the eats (just had one red bull for $3.50 which seemed regular priced).<br><br>I&#39;d return here to catch another local show or performance.

I suppose ratings are relative to what you go in expecting, and to be honest, when I went to The Basement Cafe I wasn&#39;t expecting much.<br><br>I wasn&#39;t able to try many of their food items, but they seem to target the mid range casual cafe crowd and they do okay.<br><br>The Mr Bennie, or technically a Eggs Royale, was pretty good. The egg was cooked just right, the Hollandaise was decent, and they didn&#39;t scrimp on the smoked salmon.<br><br>The chicken pie was pretty decent too, though a wee bit soggy.<br><br>There&#39;s a decent selection of cider, including my favourite Brother&#39;s Ginger, selling for $10.<br><br>So overall, average ambience, acceptable food, decent prices. Don&#39;t think they&#39;re trying to be anything more than that, so A-OK!
