text: I know of this place thanks to a Yelper who recommended it. Not the easiest place to find as I had to use the goggle map to find its exact location. Located at Shaw Tower along Beach Road, its on the ground flour, just walk all the way in and you find it. Interior of this ice cream place looks ordinary and you would think this is just a normal ice cream place but wait till you try the flavours. I was amazed with some of the unique flavours such as the Granny&#39;s favourite and the Salted Egg Yolk flavours, you can&#39;t get this anywhere else at least to me. <br><br>There are so many other flavours to try, but having only one stomach, I got to take it easy. So coming back here is definitely in my agenda.

text: What a place with unique flavors, excellent customer service, and reasonable prices. I got the Honey Lavender ice cream with Banana Walnut (you can choose 2 flavors, even for the smallest size) and paid $3.60. The employees there are not shy about offering samples for their unique flavors, which I also appreciated. A great place to hit up after having spicy food next door at Ah Loy Thai!

text: I have been doing myself a tremendous disservice by never checking this place out until now :( To think I spent three months interning across the road but never made Tom&#39;s Palette a priority....<br><br>The best part about Tom&#39;s are the inventive, delicious flavors. It may be easy to dump thimbles of yuzu syrup into the ice cream machine but it&#39;s difficult to produce ice cream of the right sweetness and texture. Flavors include grannys favorite, salted caramel cheesecake, berries and split, pi pa gao, and of course usuals like chocolate, strawberry. <br><br>I highly recommend the yuzu flavor!! It&#39;s sweet, light and refreshing. We also tried a mix of chocolate and grannys favorite (a mix of chocolate, malt, marshmallows, i think?), and spent awhile chilling in the spacious interior. There&#39;re many tables and it reminds me of those student haunts at Upper Thomson. (also, ah loy thai right opposite is SUPERB- another excuse to visit Toms!)<br><br>I wish there were more independent creameries/ice cream shops like Toms, Daily Scoop, Creamier... I&#39;ve gotta play my part in supporting and frequenting them ;)

Salted egg yolk ice cream yummmm", 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Salted egg yolk ice cream yummmm'}]
text: Now, getting there wasn&#39;t super easy because it&#39;s not very close to Bugis MRT, but this shop is nestled in an old building. Sort of dingy if you ask me.<br><br>I sampled a few flavors but I only really wanted to try the salted egg yolk one because I am a liu sha bao afterall. I thoroughly enjoyed my ice cream, but I suspect it was made with salted egg yolk powder, not salted egg yolk itself. Nonetheless delicious, until I found a lump of cold, hard, butter on the second last spoonful. <br><br>I nearly fainted from the revelation that a good load of butter was used in the production of my ice cream. But... 4 stars it is! And yes, I would most defo come back.

I love the range of choices at Tom&#39;s Palette and they do change it quite frequently. But somehow I always end up with my absolute 2 favorites &#34;Granny&#39;s favorite&#34; and &#34;Chocolate&#34; despite tasting the other flavors. <br><br>Granny&#39;s favorite is just soooo goood that I am loathe to eat other flavors. If I remembered correctly, it has some horlicks to it and is a bit malty. I am not sure if they still allow it, but I used to be able to get 2 flavors in a cup (not 2 scoops). I thought that was a very nice practice as sometimes you do not want to have an entire cup of the same flavor. <br><br>The chocolate is rich and dark, a bit bittersweet, just the way I like my chocolate, with no fillers or cheap ingredients ruining the taste.

I don&#39;t know how someone would just come across this place by chance. It&#39;s tucked away down a hallway that doesn&#39;t appear to get much foot traffic. I don&#39;t think there&#39;s any signage on the street outside either.<br><br>I recently visited on a Tuesday afternoon and the building was dead, except for a handful of people having ice cream here. But it is worth the trip. An excellent variety of traditional and non-traditional flavors with good texture. Perfect antidote to hot, humid Singapore days.

Alas, I have downgraded my review to four stars. Still exceptional ice cream - the melt and sizzle is very tasty while &#39;a nasty mix&#39; is a little too sweet for my palate. This time I got a medium of the latter and salted caramel cheesecake. The cheesecake was scrumptious but the nasty mix (caramel, nuts, and chocolate) was far too sweet. <br><br>Very busy on a Friday evening so the service was rushed, but that is to be expected.

Ice cream", 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Ice cream'}]
text: Never knew there were such ice cream flavors in existence until.  Sample the hottest flavors, typically 4-5.  Either the conniseurs recommends or the trays with less than half left to scoop from should hint preference.  The &#34;rum &amp; favourite&#34;.

Signboard of shop", 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Signboard of shop'}]
text: Great, hidden place in Bugis for fantastic ice cream. It&#39;s in one corner of the Shaw building across the road from the row of shophouses near Bugis Junction. There&#39;s a variety of flavors and the speciality is the layers in textures with ingredients rather than just plain ice cream. The flavors change from time to time and when I visited, a few caught my eye: salted egg yolk, white chocolate nori (seaweed), grandma&#39;s favorite (chocolate, malt, dough) and yuzu etc. Customer service was very good and sample servings were big! :P

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/jppn-9mV57ScQjYATGlH0g/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/toms-palette-singapore?reviewid=CvhHTQiHbWyUFeOqFxfkXA&select=jppn-9mV57ScQjYATGlH0g', 'altText': "Photo of Tom's Palette - Singapore, Singapore. Mocha Mac Nut + Melt &amp; Sizzle", 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Mocha Mac Nut + Melt & Sizzle'}]
text: Tom&#39;s Palette is easily my favourite ice cream joint in Singapore. It&#39;s got interesting flavours which change all the time, friendly staff and prices as well as an overall fun casual vibe.<br><br>Food : I&#39;m in love with the Melt &amp; Sizzle. A mixture of berries and chocolate chunks already sounds pretty amazing, but wait till the pop rocks zing and sizzle on your tongue ... making it a regular party in your mouth! I also love the Mocha Macnut, which as its name says, is a generous mixture of macadamia nuts in mocha ice cream. The rose and lavender flavours are also really unique for those who appreciate something novel and light (which I do) but as my ice cream philistine of a friend remarks, it could feel like &#34;eating potpurri&#34;. The salted caramel is also really good but I tend to like texture in my ice cream, so I get bored after a spoonful or two.<br><br>Ambience : Fun and casual<br><br>Service : Polite and friendly<br><br>Shaw Towers is a bit out of the way for me but I try to make a pilgrimage there once a month.

Fresh update!!<br>Triple coconut even better than the previously reviewed coconut. <br><br>Dublin coffee is awesome with a hint of Guinness <br><br>Toms Palette always surprises with wonderful flavours. The ice cream texture, however, is less than perfect but that&#39;s okay. The flavours make up for it. Test drive a couple of flavours before you commit.

Interesting flavours to cool you down in warm humid Singapore! Throughly enjoyed the egg waffles topped with chilli chocolate and salted egg! Definitely favours that shouts local and hardly available elsewhere. Friendly and enthusiastic service tops it off!

Their salted caramel cheesecake ice cream is just brilliant. It&#39;s my most favorite ice cream EVER. The flavor is just so rich and indescribable - sweet and savory at the same time, each scoop is pure delight.<br><br>Pair this with granny&#39;s favorite and you&#39;ve got my idea of the perfect ice cream duo. Granny&#39;s favorite is chocolate ice cream with random burst of malt that seem to complement salted caramel cheesecake perfectly.<br><br>I&#39;ve yet to try other flavors from tom&#39;s just because i was so blown away by these two flavors that i always end up going for them.. I need to be more adventurous eh!

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=xU3sDPonLx1_w4t6wOOpdg', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/2tpNJsz2hcEol8OYpL7nSQ/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/2tpNJsz2hcEol8OYpL7nSQ/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/2tpNJsz2hcEol8OYpL7nSQ/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/2tpNJsz2hcEol8OYpL7nSQ/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/2tpNJsz2hcEol8OYpL7nSQ/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/2tpNJsz2hcEol8OYpL7nSQ/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Ting Yi C.', 'displayLocation': 'Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Ting Yi C.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=xU3sDPonLx1_w4t6wOOpdg', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 30, 'photoCount': 6, 'reviewCount': 194, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Impressed with the innovative flavours of the ice cream but slightly disappointed with the taste. Had the salted cheesecake and salted coconut flavours. Both were too sweet for my liking. But overall, I would say if you have a sweet tooth and love to try interesting flavours like salted egg yolk and other alcoholic flavours then this place is for you.

I agree with Adri on this one. Discovering Tom&#39;s Palette is across the road from my office is like opening a bag of kettle chips. The style of ice cream made there is totally up my alley: fresh, dense on your spoon but light and smooth on your tongue. Sure I&#39;m a purist at times and like my ice cream clean with just one flavor but when you have mix-in&#39;s done right at Tom&#39;s, I promise you it is futile to resist.  <br><br>I&#39;ve had the savory something (can&#39;t remember the name), chocolate sorbet, Nuts and such (well basically all the nut variants), a tea-based flavor... and I have yet to fail to completely lick my cup clean. In other words, picky me has not found anything bad about their ice cream and that is ridiculous. Annnd I can&#39;t even bother to remember the flavors because I&#39;m too busy stuffing it down. <br><br>The cafe itself looks like a napkin monster vomited all over the place and 3 year old&#39;s decided they couldn&#39;t let all that white stuff go to waste. Eat your ice cream, enjoy it and close your eyes if you have to.

A place to sit and enjoy your ice cream", 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'A place to sit and enjoy your ice cream'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/orY2WSNKKDsjemIJWrPpkQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/toms-palette-singapore?reviewid=OU9MYYCwjlPb6h1JvtNG8w&select=orY2WSNKKDsjemIJWrPpkQ', 'altText': "Photo of Tom's Palette - Singapore, Singapore", 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': ''}]
text: Tom&#39;s Palette was my first dalliance with &#39;artisan&#39; ice cream, and I definitely put on weight in my 6-month internship because I kept popping downstairs for ice cream breaks.<br><br>While there are a zillion fancy ice cream shops out there these days, Tom&#39;s Palette remains one of my favourites because it has such great flavours. At any one time there is a wide range to choose from, and the flavours are always changing; they do really great local and seasonal flavours (Pineapple Tart Ice cream during Chinese New Year REALLY tastes like pineapple tarts!), but their simple flavours like Chocolate and Vanilla are also done exceptionally well.<br><br>Another small but important point - Tom&#39;s Palette allows you to mix 2 flavours even in their smallest cup so you don&#39;t have to settle on just one flavour (the pain of having to choose!).

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/p-guy5TAfBxKNU8D2aJrzg/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/toms-palette-singapore?reviewid=1oQmSAhci_JS81YgXneGog&select=p-guy5TAfBxKNU8D2aJrzg', 'altText': "Photo of Tom's Palette - Singapore, Singapore", 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': ''}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/BfW3N7qKShGacCsUaOLuzw/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/toms-palette-singapore?reviewid=1oQmSAhci_JS81YgXneGog&select=BfW3N7qKShGacCsUaOLuzw', 'altText': "Photo of Tom's Palette - Singapore, Singapore", 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': ''}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Uhj1IiKHekbR8wLETiwxqQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/toms-palette-singapore?reviewid=1oQmSAhci_JS81YgXneGog&select=Uhj1IiKHekbR8wLETiwxqQ', 'altText': "Photo of Tom's Palette - Singapore, Singapore", 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': ''}]
text: This place is tucked in a corner of Shaw Leisure Gallery, just before the food court. Basically, you can have 2 flavours of ice cream for all sizes; they&#39;re not cheap but really quite worth it for the taste. Beside ice cream, you can have milk shake, waffles and hot tea too.<br>I have the salted egg yolk ice cream, which was partly inspired by the Hong Kong yolk-filled custard buns in. It taste like the salted egg yolk found in mooncake, but surprisingly it&#39;s not salty, with a tad of sweetness, creamy, rich and filled with yolk in grainy forms. It was surprisingly good and really a refreshing take on the good old ice cream.<br><br>I also had my usual favorite, Chocolate. It was quite chocolatey and really one of the best chocolate ice creams that I&#39;ve had. <br><br>Overall, this is really one of my favorite ice cream places around.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/BzZZdguwcdUasXqElNM9vw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/toms-palette-singapore?reviewid=sChT-ggsTUwwe--ho2tmew&select=BzZZdguwcdUasXqElNM9vw', 'altText': "Photo of Tom's Palette - Singapore, Singapore", 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: Tom&#39;s Palette is a shop selling a wide variety of ice creams, most of them being self-creations. It is situated right opposite another famous delight, Ah Loy Thai, at level one inside Shaw Towers. You will be greeted by a group of friendly staff, who will offer to let you try a number of flavours which you request or they recommend.<br><br>Some of the more popular ones are granny&#39;s favourite, rum &amp; raisin and salted caramel cheesecake. I myself would prefer summer berries, as someone who like fruits. They will also create some new flavours every now and then, so do try them out and some might just keep you coming back!<br><br>They even allow you to mix two flavours in a cup so in case you are indecisive, just pick another flavour! Their prices range from a small cup at $3.20, a medium one at $4 to a large one at $5. If you happen to be from schools like SIM, SMU, NTU, NUS (Check out their website for the full list), you will even be entitled a 10% off!

Fantastic. So many creative and delicious flavors I had a really hard time choosing. I sampled at least 6 different ones and just ended up picking randomly because there was no clear favorite - they were all so good! 5 stars for the creativity - many sweet/savory combos, flavors with extras mixed in, and unexpected flavors that work really well.<br><br>Ended up choosing the melt &amp; sizzle (with bits of berry and chocolate pieces) and brown sugar/cinnamon.  Yumm<br><br>Not a fan of the location, but I can&#39;t take away a star for that. It&#39;s hidden down the hallway on the right hand side of the lobby of the building on the corner of Middle and Beach Rds. Definitely worth seeking out.

The flavors and taste of the Ice-Creams here are as good as it gets.<br><br>The amount of Savory Ice-Cream they serve includes a lot of different Local Taste. For 2 scoops of Ice-Cream it is at a very affordable price of $3.40. <br><br>The must try for the place is the slated eggyolk Ice-Cream. This particular flavor packs a punch, as the smoothness of both the egg and the cream come very well together. The taste of the yolk is distinct but not too over powering. I&#39;ve tried this flavor and it was superb. It is also the pick among a lot of people who frequents this place. <br><br>People who love ice-cream should go for the Granny&#39;s Favorite, Rum &amp; Chocolate, Savory Crunch and for Coffee Lovers, You can try the Coffee Cheesecake. There are a lot of different flavors to choose from and depending on your taste, mix &amp; match as You like.

Nestled in Shaw Tower&#39;s, the homemade icecream at Tom&#39;s Palette is a true gem. The icecreams have amazing depth of flavour with similar smoothness and density of Italian gelato and with all creations made from hand by Tom and his team, there is a reason why everyone loves it. <br><br>My friend had trouble deciding what icecream took his fancy. Tom the owner was happy to suggest numerous flavours and provide generous taste testers to help with the decision process. Tom shed some light on how he and his team make the icecream and the creative process in inventing new and exciting flavours. My friend decided on the chocolate sorbet which was like eating pure cocoa chocolate. It is not for a subtle palette as it is made without dairy making it very strong and rich. Luckily I was more than happy to finish of the rest when my friend had enough of the rich flavours.<br><br>I had the much raved about salted egg yolk icecream. It was interesting to say the least. It had a floury taste that coated my mouth, followed by the sweetness and creaminess of the egg yolk complimenting the saltiness.  The salted egg yolk is definitely an experience and one that I could happily relive. <br><br>After doing a bit more searching, I found out that they offer icecream lessons, normally on a Sunday. I would love to attend and learn more about the icecream making process and how the simple ingredients of egg, milk, sugar and cream can result in some truly fantastic creations. For more information, head to their website.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/3TWnB5cm09TFc3CXgXPYgQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/toms-palette-singapore?reviewid=fWdLgdxb8ZeOL4UTobwgVg&select=3TWnB5cm09TFc3CXgXPYgQ', 'altText': "Photo of Tom's Palette - Singapore, Singapore. Melt &amp; Sizzle and Salted Egg Yolk, Tom&#39;s Palette", 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': "Melt & Sizzle and Salted Egg Yolk, Tom's Palette"}]
text: I came here on the recommendation of the salted egg yolk ice cream. Being the adventurous foodie that I am, thought I couldn&#39;t miss that out.<br><br>And I thank the adventurous foodie boldness in me for giving it a go because it is just spacey out of this world! I always like a joint that colours a little bit outside the lines and dares to put unheard of yet delicious flavours out there for their customers. And Tom&#39;s Palette is one of the few places that dares to push the envelope of your taste buds! In a good way.<br><br>Also tried the much-raved about Melt&amp;Sizzle - the staff recommended it to me. Absolutely adore the idea of having pop rocks in your ice cream, you&#39;ll feel like charlie in the ice cream factory with their creative creations and I can&#39;t wait to taste more new flavours!

This is my favourite ice cream place in Singapore. I don&#39;t care how many fancy new homemade ice cream places pop up here (seriously, why do people mix crap into their ice cream... and put up with light-as-air &#39;healthier&#39;/&#39;egg-free&#39;/&#39;less-sugar&#39; bullshit?!) /Serious ice cream angst over<br><br>Everything is so no-nonsense, no-frills here, even their decor. Thankfully their ice-cream-making madskillz are far better than their interior design skillz. I&#39;m convinced they are mad geniuses. Try the sea salt caramel ice cream. Or Granny&#39;s Favourite. When they have the mad flavours, like the salted egg yolk or potato-chip-flavoured ice cream, TRY THEM ALL.<br><br>Even the regular chocolate is the best, IMHO.<br><br>I could eat a few tubs a day and live happily in largesse.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=k4B4gZFiZscBR9yFFUsc6Q', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/N9odUC2l-kWNjHWp_YyhyA/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/N9odUC2l-kWNjHWp_YyhyA/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/N9odUC2l-kWNjHWp_YyhyA/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/N9odUC2l-kWNjHWp_YyhyA/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/N9odUC2l-kWNjHWp_YyhyA/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/N9odUC2l-kWNjHWp_YyhyA/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Zhi Hao Y.', 'displayLocation': 'Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Zhi Hao Y.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=k4B4gZFiZscBR9yFFUsc6Q', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 2, 'photoCount': 180, 'reviewCount': 178, 'eliteYear': None}
text: This is one of the best home made ice cream I have tasted so far. The shop has similar style as other ice cream stall such as Udders. However the ice creams flavour they offer are very creative and unique. <br><br>Do check out their flavour of the month and you will be surprised to find exotic flavours which you will never expect to appear as ice cream. Occasionally they do have mini challenge such as mystery flavours and chili challenge. <br><br>If you are an alcholic ice cream fan, do give their rum and raisin and chocolate stout a try. The rum and raisin is well balance between the rum and the sweetness of the rum and the chocolate stout simply compliments each other. <br><br>Remember to flash your student card for some discount!

Before the icecream story started, Chronos was working in the mechanical engineering industry -- not quite something we would associate with the sweet treat.<br><br>Just 8 years ago, Chronos decided to create his own cold plate inspired by the icecream brands he came into contact with overseas. Completing it after a year, he decided to start creating his own unique icecream flavours, many of which we find in-stores today.<br><br>Melt &amp; Sizzle was a fun flavour to try with pops inside the icecream (they literally crack in your mouth!) as well as the flavourful Chocolate Sorbet. They also have new flavours from time to time but you have a safe bet with the classic flavours too!

Tucked in a quiet corner of Shaw Towers is Tom&#39;s Palette, an unpretentious shop that sells homemade ice cream. I usually go to Tom&#39;s Palette in weekday afternoons to avoid the crazy after work or weekend crowds. That weekday, the friendly staff warmly welcomed us into the shop with genuine smiles on their faces, leaving a great impression. They also graciously allowed customers to try as many flavors as they wanted, before they decided on their purchase.<br><br>Tom&#39;s Palette concoct original ice cream flavors to suit the local palate - Coconut, Horlicks, Sarsi and Salted Egg Yolk to name a few. I ordered a medium cup with 2 flavors - Granny&#39;s Favorite and Rum &amp; Raisin. Granny&#39;s Favorite is one of their best sellers here and it is no wonder, since it is a smooth blend of chocolate, malt, and chocolate chip cookie dough. Though not overly sweet, it is sufficiently sweet to give you a sugar rush for the entire day. The rum in Rum &amp; Raisin was prominent, with bitter rum-soaked Raisins that were satisfying.

Everyone loves ice cream, and if you&#39;re a ice cream lover, try Tom&#39;s Palette!<br><br>Firstly, their ice cream flavours are all created by the owners themselves, and it not only taste so good, you&#39;ve leave the place smiling like a little kid.<br><br>Yes, as most have already recommended, try the salted egg ice cream. Even if you&#39;re not a fan of salted egg, the unique and interesting taste might change your taste in salted egg. I&#39;m serious! It&#39;s sweet, like ice cream should be and yet the taste of salted egg is rich and strong. I couldn&#39;t help imagining the actual salted egg.<br><br>Or, you can try the Granny&#39;s favourite. I&#39;ll definitely put that in my recommendation list.<br><br>Pen down your thoughts and write your little notes around the shop too.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=05tSDymzhXyvaxO1G24d0g', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/1OWecEUpQD4ARlRM_Nswbg/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/1OWecEUpQD4ARlRM_Nswbg/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/1OWecEUpQD4ARlRM_Nswbg/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/1OWecEUpQD4ARlRM_Nswbg/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/1OWecEUpQD4ARlRM_Nswbg/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/1OWecEUpQD4ARlRM_Nswbg/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Pui Yeng C.', 'displayLocation': 'Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Pui Yeng C.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=05tSDymzhXyvaxO1G24d0g', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 29, 'photoCount': 185, 'reviewCount': 185, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Amongst the various hot spots for yummy food at Shaw Towers is the famous ice cream store Tom&#39;s Palette. With a simple and bright layout, the store itself seemed welcoming enough, and it was brilliantly located right opposite Ah Loy&#39;s Thai. We&#39;ve been gluttons many a time, getting up from our spicy Thai meal, and strolling 3 steps across the corridor to Tom&#39;s for a scoop or two of creamy ice cream to put out the flames on our tongue. <br><br>My favourite is the Horlicks paired with &#39;Granny&#39;s Favourite&#39;, which is a malty chocolate flavor. It tastes a lot milkier and creamier than the usual ice cream, to the point where it&#39;s almost the consistency of gelato - I like! Since they pride themselves in creating a new flavor each month, I love trying out some of their more &#39;innovative&#39; ice creams, like Oolong Tea, Wasabi Lime and Red Wine Ice Cream. Although some of them are too extreme for me to have a full scoop, I still give 5 stars for creativity and persistence in their concept!

Tom&#39;s Palette has been both my source of joy and woe. Joy - because they always have a great new flavor to try, woe - because after multiple ice cream pig-out sessions, I could hardly squeeze into my office shirts anymore. <br><br>The first defining trait of this local-grown parlour is the awesome variety they have. Even their traditional staples are whacky in their own way. I&#39;ve always enjoyed the chocolate stout, Granny&#39;s favourite (a mix of banana and chocolate), and salted egg yolk ice cream. On my last visit, I had their Breakfast flavor - a delicious mix of kaya and banana toffee. If you want to turn on the sinful factor, mix two flavors in milkshake form. The day I tried their Hazelnut and Rum &amp; Raisin I was torn between a world of bliss, and the worry that I&#39;d suffer from cardiac arrest. <br><br>The price hardly does the quality justice. At $3.50 for a small scoop of 2 flavors, you can&#39;t get any better. The sheer range of the selection will make you want to come back, and bring all your friends.

Try their salted egg yolk ice cream.<br><br>Yes, that is one of the flavors they have there, and the most interesting one! It created quite a hoo-ha when we tried it among ourselves. General consensus was it is very good. There is this grainy taste much like having real salted egg, but cushioned with the sweet icy taste of frozen milk.<br><br>Other flavors which I like include the ones with the magic dust that sizzles and pops in your mouth and their salted caramel. I think most of their flavors are excellent so it really is up to personal choice. <br><br>It can get really noisy and crowded on weekends though so be prepared for it. Not an ideal place for chit chats, definitely. Just enjoy your cup of goodness and go.

^whatever Adrianna said<br><br>You know what makes it more impressive? It&#39;s not plain chocolate ice cream that they make--it&#39;s chocolate sorbet. No milk, no cream, all good chocolatey richness and you wouldn&#39;t even know it!<br><br>I love them for the quality of their flavours, the consistency of the ice cream (are you surprised that Tom was an engineer?) Everything has a point--it&#39;s not alcohol for alcohol&#39;s sake (my favorite flavour is chocolate stout--you don&#39;t taste the booze, you taste the richness), it&#39;s not mix-ins, for the sake of mix-ins, or worse, weirdness for the sake of weirdness. There are some great local flavours (Thai tea! mango sticky rice!), and some things that push the envelope (salted egg, anyone?), and the staff are enthusiastic about making sure you taste and sample before making a selection.<br><br>I really appreciate that Tom&#39;s does a children&#39;s size too--quality counts for so much more than quantity. OMNOMNOM

I had Mocha Macnut (mocha ice cream with white chocolated coated macadamia and almond nuts) and Milk Ice Cream. The Mocha Macnut tasted more chocolatey and the bits of crunchy macadamia and almond nuts made it even nicer. The Milk Ice Cream was full on milk flavour. Nothing else to describe it although it lacks behind other places which offered similar milk flavours which tasted more concentrated.

text: Sweaty and thirsty after walking around at high noon in the gardens?<br><br>This place is a welcoming spot in spite of the crowds. And of course, there will be crowds as the gardens attract hundreds of tourists each day. <br><br>This tastefully designed cafe evokes casual brunch fare, sandwiches and salads. I just had lunch so I stopped by for a cocktail and cake, because , why the hell not! <br><br>The namesake Bee&#39;s Knees cocktail (S$18) packs a sting ;) despite the addition of honey in there. Made with sapphire gin and lime, it was a delightful cocktail to cool me down. The coconut shortcake (S$7) that came with my order bordered on the very sweet side, so I only had a few bites. <br><br>Wander off and be sure to check out the Stingless Bee houses at the Ethnobotany garden. Enjoy and BEE happy!

text: The food honestly doesn&#39;t look that great but the service, drink, and boomin AC are worth the trip after walking through the garden.   I can&#39;t speak highly enough about the service, they&#39;re so nice.

It&#39;s a great location to stop while you&#39;re exploring the gardens to refresh. The food was good as was the service. I thought the prices were a tad high, but not overly so. There is an indoor section with air conditioning if you get over heated while walking around.

text: Good atmosphere, and has a great location, right in the beautiful Botanic Gardens. Nice music taste, and the service is polite and quick. The coffee is very strong, and the cups were a bit small, and the strength gave the coffee a rather bitter taste, but the root beer float was a good size, and had a lovely taste with a scoop of ice cream. Not too crowded, and not too much hustle and bustle. The place bakes it&#39;s own bread, and cooks pretty good meals right from it&#39;s own kitchen. If the coffee was more refined, this could be a gem within a large rainforest. I would recommend this for a quick snack and drink.

text: Located on the 4th floor is this quiet cafe tucked  in YMCA which interestingly is at the begining of Orchard Road, just 5 mins walk away from dhoby ghaut MRT.<br><br>They have a wide range of choice of high tea ranging from sandwiches, cakes and even gelato at $6++<br><br>I went with Papitto Gelato which is delivered here from their ubi headquarters.<br><br>They have a wide range of flavours and was told by the friendly staff that durian was the most popular.<br><br>Sadly durian was all sold out! So I went with Tiramisu, the next best option recommended by the friendly staff.<br><br>There&#39;s ample seating in this quiet and quaint cafe. There&#39;s also an outdoor seating area which is normally reserved for functions.<br><br>The gelato itself tasted quite powdery and didn&#39;t quite like it. It did have a light tiramisu taste and I had to wait a good 5 minutes before I was able to sink the metal tea spoon into the frozen tiramisu.<br><br>I do like the ambience in this cafe and the staff were very helpful and friendly. I might come back here to try other foods and maybe the durian flavoured gelato.

A very nice interior drew us there for brunch.<br><br>Alas it does not make up for eye watering prices and practices such as not offering ice water (instead, you have to pay for your water) and a 2 hour then return the table policy.<br><br>Portion size was small, which was expected, but the food was average, which was unexpected given the popularity and look of the place. The avocado chunks were literally black in half the cases - not just lightly oxidised but thoroughly black throughout - no self respecting chef would have served that. The hummus lacked salt. The $10 grapefruit juice they call a &#34;no-tail&#34; was not really worth it. The cocktails looked better. We walked on to Common Man to top up the calories despite spending over $100++, rather than try the desserts.<br><br>I recognised a few people from the hip crowd (including a Vogue cover). For some reason this place is &#34;cool&#34; right now, perhaps the great interior which beats the usual drab school chairs and tables with raw concrete, perhaps the fans which make the heat bearable, perhaps the lack of options nearby. Tables are very close together and the one next to us was quite interested in our conversation.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/HCk_i-lQ2_MtCO2un0tZjw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/summerlong-singapore?reviewid=bWcUZyvCdQTdyJcvV0_Hfg&select=HCk_i-lQ2_MtCO2un0tZjw', 'altText': 'Photo of Summerlong - Singapore, Singapore. Brioche French Toast: $19.00 SGD', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Brioche French Toast: $19.00 SGD'}]
text: After reflecting on what were some truly spectacular Singapore breakfast dishes at both Clinton Street and Common Man, it really brought home the contrast to what was some disappointing french toast over at Summerlong. <br><br>Star 1: How were the service and atmosphere?<br><br>The atmosphere at Summerling is really great, although be advised that if it&#39;s raining, they need to roll out the overhang covers, which can make the whole place seem a bit dark. From there, service was fast and friendly enough. Star. <br><br>Star 2: How were the portions relative to the cost?<br><br>$19.00 for brioche french toast was pricey, but very much on par with other spots catering to tourists and expats like Clinton Street and Common Man. Star. <br><br>Stars 3 and 4: How was the food?<br><br>This was just not good, and I&#39;m struggling to articulate why. The brioche bread itself was fluffy on the inside and crispy on the outside, which is exactly what you want, but it had absolutely no flavor, there was virtually no syrup, and it didn&#39;t get a lot of help from what were weak raspberries and very flavorless tiny little blueberries (if that&#39;s what they were). The highlight was the caramelized banana. No Stars. <br><br>Star 5: Would you be excited to go back?<br><br>Negative. No Star.

text: I used to live in the area near Yio Chu Kang Road and during one of my walks I found this small cafe by Brighton Cres st. Told my flatmates and we go there once a week (Sundays). I&#39;m just writing this review now because I miss this place!<br><br>I love their Salmon steak ( it was so good). I also love their bread pudding, their lasangna. Most of all, we always buy their Brioche bread... I had brioche before but nothing as tasty as Sun Ray&#39;s.<br><br>They&#39;re also pet friendly and has a dog food menu so that&#39;s a plus!

text: Hidden, pet-friendly gem near Serangoon gardens. Salmon pesto pasta was surprisingly good, while the iced brighton was a bit too chocolate-y for my liking. Admittedly not the most comfortable cafe to relax in, but the dogs more than make up for it :)

text: Situated 2 doors down from &#34;The Coffee Daily&#34;, is Sun Ray Cafe, you can find parallel parking HDB spot right in front of it, on a monday night at 8pm, there was parking, the cafe had 4 other tables occupied and an owner brought a dog too which made me somewhat excited to see dogs and their owners dining in the same restaurant. Maybe I&#39;ll bring my dog here too next time!<br><br>So considering &#34;The Coffee Daily&#34;&#39;s infamous rainbow cake priced at $10 nett usually gets sold out in the afternoon, and it was indeed sold out when I got there at 8pm, the Sun Ray Cafe also sells rainbow cake! :) <br><br>Rainbow cake - $8+<br>So this is probably not their best selling point, but hey! if you are craving a rainbow cake at $8+, it will satisfy your cravings, the cake was pretty much frozen when we got it, we cam whored with it for a bit while waiting for it to melt. The butter cream was not too sweet.<br><br>Chocolate banana cake - $8+<br>At $8+, it wasn&#39;t too bad, but it was very solid and jerlat too. The chocolate was very dense and I could sense &#34;heaty-ness&#34; in my throat, since I wasn&#39;t willing to run the extra km on the treadmill I shoved it to my guy friend to finish it up. <br><br>Fish and Chips- $12+<br>The truffle chips was the best part about this dish, you could smell the flavourful truffle oil, the second they placed the dish on the table. The fish itself was quite oily to be honest, the wasabi mayo was a nice change from the normal mayo. <br><br>All in all, a decent cafe in the serangoon gardens area, but I wouldn&#39;t travel all the way there, if I wasn&#39;t in the area. But if you have pets, you might want to try and take them here, they sell pet cafe food too :D

Corn soup', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Corn soup'}]
text: A happy happy place... <br><br>... Or at least for me. To be surrounded by four legged friends running around, all being sociable and oh-so-adorable! <br><br>And I was surprised that the food was good too! I ordered their set which allowed me one soup, a main and a drink. So I had corn soup (good), fettuccine carbonara (very good) and a cup of cold coffee (my friend said their hot coffees are not too bad, my cold coffee had a hint of sourness in it which I&#39;m not that big of a fan of). <br><br>If you are not a big fan of dogs (shame on you...), you can always go next door - same cafe but doggies are not allowed there. <br><br>For the dogs, there is a menu for them too! Be prepared for wait abit, and the food does come a wee bit hot for the doggies. Though I must say that the two little four legged ones that I went with didn&#39;t seem to have too much of a problem with that. They are bowl available for the doggies for them to drink water, and mops are available in case of &#34;accidents&#34; :)

text: Nestled in a residential neighbourhood, this is the nearest cafe at Brighton unless you wish to walk to Serangoon Gardens. I like the laid back charm and that they allow dogs into the cafe. Food was so-so although the duck confit was flavourful.

text: Sun Ray just newly reopened after about 2 weeks of renovations and the place looks AMAZING :) Previously, it never really caught my eye but after its new face-lift I decided to give this place a go. Plus, my family recently adopted a dog, Pika, so I thought it would be great to socialize him with some of his furry friends. Sun Ray is one of the few pet friendly cafes in Singapore. They allow you take the leash off your pooch on the premise provided you clean up after it. Pooch are allowed on chairs and they even have a special dog menu :) <br><br>So Pika and I headed there on a lazy Sunday afternoon. Initially, I was just going to order a cup of coffee and read on my kindle while Pika did his social rounds but I never got around to it. Instead I spent my time chatting with other dog lovers and joined them in the ritual of fawning and fussing over our pets. Pika picked out a BFF among 4 or 5 other dogs. She was a beautiful white poodle-maltese named Yumi and they played non-stop for 2 hours straight chasing each all over the restaurant. 0.0 In the end, I decided to have dinner there too since I could not bear to tear him away from his new found best friend. I decided to order a eggs benny. The eggs benny was served with a delicious cone instead of bread. It was the best part of the dish. <br><br>A lesser known fact is that Sun Ray makes really really really good coffee. Think Nylon coffee good. Their barista Charmaine was kind enough to chat with me on different types of coffee and show me the equipment they used to make it. This is what I recalled from our conversation, <br><br>1. The French pressed method - gives a sweeter taste to the brew. <br><br>2. The Siphon method - gives the coffee a clearer appearance.<br><br>3. The Pour over method - gives it a stronger and richer taste.<br><br>*varies accordingly with the beans used, of course :) <br><br>I ordered a flat white with soya milk. They used the brand Pacific. My first time trying it but it was as good as &#34;boysoy&#34; (not sure the exact spelling of this brand even though I had it multiple times). Overall, their coffee blew me away. I was not expecting such a high standard of coffee for a pet cafe? It totally beats The Coffee Daily (just next door). Sun Ray takes their coffee seriously and I&#39;ll definitely be back for more! I know Pika cannot wait to go back too :) <br><br>PS: Charmaine cordially invites our coffee expert &amp; beloved CM to try her brews!!! She&#39;s always excited to meet a fellow barista!

text: I&#39;ve had several aeropress coffees here and they don&#39;t disappoint. At times I&#39;ve also asked for options out of the menu, and they are always willing to oblige. Free wifi and best of all are the prices. I can&#39;t recall any cafes that offer boutique brews at $2 a cup. Friendly service from the barista KK made each visit pleasant.

text: Go for hand brew coffee if you&#39;re a coffee lover. I personally liked the risotto but if you&#39;re not a fan, I wouldn&#39;t recommend as it tasted unique unlike the average risotto you had at other restaurants. I would recommend for the truffle fries also. Somewhat disappointed at the tiramisu, too overwhelmed by the nuts and the top cream was bland.

text: Had a brighton, latte and truffle fries (i know its weird but i just had to try). Coffee here is okay, was rather disappointed with the truffle fries(just drench in truffle oil with those thin kind of fries). If i had a pet dog to bring to this place i would rate it a 4 but since i am here just to try the coffee and dessert(which they seem to run out of the toast and the tiramisu i wanted) it felt like a 3. Maybe if i get bored with other nearby cafes i will come back to try the mains to give it a fairer judgement.

Sun Ray cafe recently completed renovation gave them a new chic interior (though cramped) and i was glad to see that the menu is more streamlined and coffee is now playing a bigger role. Coffee appreciation courses are conducted here now and you can enjoy various coffee brewed using different techniques such as syphon, cold-brew, French press, and own specialty drip coffee. The folks even have their  own custom-roasted blend, called the Brighton blend.<br> <br>Needless to say, i got really high after sampling the various coffees. I quite enjoyed the latte and the iced mocha wasn&#39;t too shady as well. The cold brew will send your brain and heart into overdrive. Try it at your own risk! Now if only they serve better desserts to go with my coffee. After all, a good cafe has to have the entire package and that includes good sweets to accompany the coffee. <br><br>The homemade scones ($3), which were promised to be crusty and buttery, fell terribly short of my expectation. This is not a scone. It&#39;s a cross between a bun and a really soft tart. I finished half the chocolate scone because i wanted to eat the chocolate chips. The blueberry and strawberry (or was it raspberry) ones reminded me of the Arnott&#39;s tartlets in terms of flavor. The crust was not even as crisp as Artnott&#39;s. Meh. <br><br>I shall not even discuss the cupcakes ($3). Go figure. The Tiramisu ($6.50) weren&#39;t that bad after they defrosted. I believe SRC is working on adding more coffee to that recipe after our feedback. <br><br>The Oven-Baked Escargots ($8.90 half-dozen | $15.90 one dozen) were well flavored with the garlic and parsley butter. They are typically served in the escargot pot but this was for our tasting purposes. <br><br>The Wild Mushroom Soup ($7.90) was made fresh and came served with the perfumed truffle oil. I love the thick, creamy and smooth texture and intense flavor of this one. <br><br>My favorite dish was the Carbonara ($12.90). This is the dish that i&#39;ll come back to SRC for (since it&#39;s in da hood). I&#39;m glad that this pasta isn&#39;t swimming in sauce. This was pretty salty but i love that each mouthful had the smoky meat flavor of the bacon and each strand was nicely coated with sticky cream, raw egg yolk and cheese. Too good... <br><br>J enjoyed the Cumin Crusted Lamb Rack ($23.90) which was served with ratatouille and rosemary sauce. The meat was tender and didn&#39;t have that gamey taste. The Grilled Strip Loin ($23.90) served with potato gratin and the Yorkshire Pork Rack ($23.90) with apple cider sauce both paled in comparison. Both meats were overdone and dry and we simply gave up after 2 bites (you can&#39;t say that we didn&#39;t give them a second chance). <br><br>Hits and misses at Sun Ray Cafe. I would say go for their coffee and tiramisu. The carbonara and lamb rack are worth dropping by for as well. The atmosphere is pretty AJ after their reno though. i wonder why.. Anyway, special treat for my readers on my blog.

text: Bought a box of the new Thé Noir tea infused chocolate cookies ($14 for a box of 10) for my friend who was meeting me for lunch at Japan Food Town and also a box of ironai cheese cookies/langue de chat au fromage ($12 for a box of 9) for my sister. <br><br>The staff was friendly. I guess the pricing of the product is reasonable.<br><br>LeTAO is supposedly famous for their cheesecake, specifically the Double Fromage made with imported Italian mascarpone cheese. Since they do not sell by slices, it would be too much for me to buy the whole cake and share with my mom. So I have to pass. Hopefully someone I know will get to try and let me know how it is. <br><br>LeTAO at Ion Orchard is the flagship store in Singapore. The stand alone counter is located at B1 right outside Lululemon or Coffee Bean &amp; Tea Leaf.

text: Cheap and good Thai Chinese. The trotters are delish, the tom yum is about as close to the real thing as you can get without getting on a plane to bangkok. The beef noodle soup bears an uncanny resemblance to pho and is light and flavourful. And you don&#39;t get an MSG attack after eating here

Solid 3.5 stars.<br>Bob&#39;s bar is the outdoor alfresco bar at the Capella in Singapore. Service is excellent (kind of expected for a place like Capella). Go early if you want the prime seats. We tried the chips &amp; guac and the fruit platter along with a few drinks. Food was ok, nothing extraordinary. Drinks were fine as well, though they do have a fine collection of rum. I found the views ok, plus not that much of a fan of outdoor places in balmy Singapore weather!

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Q0KiDNs3UILK_Ahm-YX7jQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/bobs-bar-singapore?reviewid=u5nBDDEPh2wUf9XnSWaF8w&select=Q0KiDNs3UILK_Ahm-YX7jQ', 'altText': "Photo of Bob's Bar - Singapore, Singapore", 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/NGErspCOqZ4E3kHP3V4jtg/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/bobs-bar-singapore?reviewid=u5nBDDEPh2wUf9XnSWaF8w&select=NGErspCOqZ4E3kHP3V4jtg', 'altText': "Photo of Bob's Bar - Singapore, Singapore", 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/dN_WZ0tAUYPEW2MKf6DkGA/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/bobs-bar-singapore?reviewid=u5nBDDEPh2wUf9XnSWaF8w&select=dN_WZ0tAUYPEW2MKf6DkGA', 'altText': "Photo of Bob's Bar - Singapore, Singapore", 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}]
text: Had a little afternoon tipple here and was very impressed. Staff was incredibly professional.<br>Cocktails were world class. Complimentary snacks were appreciated and tasty.<br>I did not stay the the Capella but if in Singapore would highly recommend coming here just to hang out.

We came here to celebrate my father&#39;s birthday. We picked Bob&#39;s because he wanted live music, and I wasn&#39;t too sure about where to get live music in Singapore. Another plus was that it was outdoors.The Havana Night event only happens on Fridays, and it&#39;s still happening. We went last October, during the haze season, and lucked out because not many people wanted to be outdoors even though the weather was fine the day of. When you&#39;re at Bob&#39;s, you really want to be outdoors where the daybeds are. It was night, so we couldn&#39;t see much. But the sea breeze was really nice. There were no peacocks the night we went, and I think it&#39;s more sanitary that way.<br><br>While Bob&#39;s is mainly a bar, they serve food too. For Havana Night, they hire a chef to BBQ outdoors, so you smell your food as it is being prepared. We ordered a couple of the Havana Night platter for two, and it served everything on the BBQ menu. My dad particularly liked the lamb. The shrimp with mango salsa was really good too. We also ordered appetizers from the menu -- I particularly liked the pizza. I don&#39;t recommend their dessert though.<br><br>For drinks, we ordered and shared a selection of cocktails. If you&#39;re uncertain, they have a set of 3 glasses of any cocktail as a sampler. Some of the cocktails incorporate Singaporean flavors, like gula melaka. For the more traditional, you can just order a shot of whisky.<br><br>As for the live music, it was a trio of men, a singer with guitar, keyboards and drums. They sing in Spanish, and it was a mix of classic and contemporary songs. Definitely crowd pleasers. If you&#39;re into Latin dancing, they will play requests too, and the singer is happy to teach the basic steps. There is plenty of dancing space.<br><br>Now being situated in the Capella hotel, home to $1000-a-night rooms, you may be a little daunted by the idea of coming to Bob&#39;s. For our party of 7, we ended up spending about $400, which was decent. We had a drink each, but we didn&#39;t drink excessively.<br><br>Bob&#39;s is a little hard to reach, so you&#39;re going to have to cab in and out. But the whole experience was magical, kind of like being transported to a whole new world. My dad had a lot of fun, and he can&#39;t wait to go back again. Yes, it&#39;s surprisingly family friendly (we&#39;re all grown ups, but a couple of older people won&#39;t stand out, unlike at some other hipper joints.)

Day beds<br>Live jazz<br>Premium free bar snacks<br>Cocktails<br>Sunset<br>Peacocks roaming around you<br>Pool view<br><br>What else do you need?<br><br>PS. Not sure who is Bob though, but Bob sure has high taste.

I love this bar.  It&#39;s obviously a bit out of the way if you don&#39;t happen to be out on Sentosa already, but the view alone is worth the trip.  You can recline on super comfy day beds while enjoying cocktails and snacking on tapas, and soaking in that view.

Blackforest steam cake ($18) - 5 stars<br>Loved this one! The chocolate cake was nice and moist but not very chocolate-y. Good if you want a cake you can eat all of, but sometimes I&#39;m in the mood for a richer cake. The cherries were delicious too.<br><br>Dark chocolate banana cheesecake ($15) - 3.5 stars<br>Tasted like your regular banana cake/loaf but it was more of a banana cream/mousse cake. I prefer the regular kind, which is more of a cake!<br><br>Marmalade bread and butter pudding cake ($16) - 3 stars<br>This had been out for a couple of hours before I had it and it was too dry.<br><br>Warning though: cakes are expensive! Prices are from Deliveroo since my friend ordered through them.

text: Food is terrible. Had the spaghetti Bolognaise. Comes served in throw away or takeaway plastic box sitting atop the noodles below. Doesn&#39;t taste good at all.<br><br>Then have to get own cutlery and napkins.<br><br>Then have to throw everything into the bin on the way out.<br><br>No service and spaghetti bolognaise was $25++. Duh!

Good food, cute store, but a lot of waste which is terrible for the environment! I understand it&#39;s the store&#39;s &#34;concept&#34; to be takeout only, but when people plan to dine in, why not serve them with reusable dishes and cutlery?!?! When I asked, they said it&#39;s all they have

text: If I&#39;m spending $5.50 on a latte, could I get it in an adult cup -a real cup, made from porcelain? After discovering this I sat to find out they don&#39;t have wifi either! A coffee/wine shop without wifi? What? Cute atmosphere otherwise. <br><br>Do you serve wine in cups as well?

Key lime pie', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Key lime pie'}]
text: I&#39;d assumed that all booze in Singapore was a total rip off until I was taken here for an afternoon &#34;snack&#34;. I&#39;d died and gone to wino heaven when I saw the beautiful shelves of wine from around the world at very reasonable prices. A lot of it comes from Australian producers I know quite well. When I worked out the conversion rate and mark up it seemed cheaper than what I&#39;d get back at home in a restaurant... and there&#39;s the trick... P.S isn&#39;t exactly a restaurant. It&#39;s essentially a bottle shop, so prices have tax included in the price and there&#39;s no service charge added. Awesome! Either take a bottle home, or if you want to sit and drink it there you can order a &#34;take away&#34; lunch or dinner from the menu and eat it from the cardboard containers.<br><br>We snacked on a giant cone of fries liberally dosed in salt, truffle and cheese (I think it was Pecorino) and washed them down with glasses of Australian Riesling for a mere $8 per glass! We might have accidentally shared a slice of the super zesty key lime pie too. Oops.

text: Not much to add that hasn&#39;t been already said about this delightful little hole in the wall cellar/pizza place.... <br><br>Great pizza ( we ummed and ahhed but eventually opted for the bolognaise with a side of chilli- excellent!...) <br>In fact...the pizza was soooo good I decided it really needed a glass of red to accompany it.... if only they sold a selection of good quality wine by the glass......they do? Brilliant!<br>Now wouldn&#39;t it be great if we could just offset the cheesey/carby/oily middle aged pizza angst/guilt with a fresh salad? We can? Double brilliant!!!<br><br>Now its off to Drips for one of those guilt free brownies and a fat free hot chocolate  to finish off the carb fest night

Wine, beautiful wine', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Wine, beautiful wine'}]
text: Well, this place hit the spot for me.<br><br>A colleague of mine was leaving the company, so we did lunch here on her last day. I&#39;ve tried their pastas in the past, and although they&#39;re delicious, I found them a bit small portion-wise. I decided to try their panini and now I&#39;m in love.<br><br>I ordered the veggie Morrocan, which comprises of portabello mushrooms, eggplant, and zucchini along with some cheese and other spices. It had beautiful grill marks and they used thin, flat bread. It was pricy at $14, but at least I felt full afterwards!<br><br>If you&#39;re dining with a friend, I do recommend splitting one of the pizzas. The all day breakfast one looks hangover worthy as it has 2 fried eggs on top, and judging from the rest of my colleagues&#39; orders, anything with meat looks appetizing.<br><br>They also offer baked goods and ice cream. I won&#39;t lie; I indulged myself by having a scoop of their apple crumble ice cream. It was amazing and worth $6 plus the Jillian Michaels kickboxing exercise video I had to suffer through after I got home from work!<br><br>The ambiance here is top notch. Dark, marble interiors surrounded by affordable wine bottles that tempt you to do a boozy lunch. What&#39;s not to love? Well, in the past, this used to be a takeaway spot, but now they have seating available.... Yet they still want to emphasize their takeaway roots by serving everything in takeaway containers. I think this just generates more excessive waste if you plan on eating in. Just invest in some real plates and silverware already, you guys can obviously afford it!

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/G7iWebSkE7IX4sCmSjNoog/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/ps-cafe-petit-singapore?reviewid=kVABFDP8nplYRPPnLFJhUA&select=G7iWebSkE7IX4sCmSjNoog', 'altText': 'Photo of PS.Cafe Petit - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: I&#39;m undoubtedly a fan.<br><br>They have a broad range of wines available as well, so you can pop in, get a pizza, a salad, and a bottle of wine to complete your dinner for the evening. (They&#39;re also open for lunch, but I&#39;m not sure if a bottle of wine makes for good post-lunch productivity.)<br><br>The majority of the pizzas here are just awesome. The Biachi Funghi, a mushroom with truffle cream white pizza is delicious. Earthy, rich, savoury, I think I&#39;d be able to finish this myself. The Fennel Sausage and Breakfast pizza are also both delicious and highly recommended.<br><br>The pizzas definite must be eaten hot, and when they are, they&#39;re gooey, delicious, and wonderful. I&#39;ve gone to PS.Cafe Petit more times than I can remember, whether for lunch, or to grab a pizza to bring home, or just for a salad when I&#39;m not inclined to all the local food on offer in the area.<br><br>This is possibly one of the most underrated pizza joints in Singapore, and while I wouldn&#39;t say it&#39;s better than Mozza, I can&#39;t say it&#39;s worse either. <br><br>My one lament is that they discontinued their Puttanesca pizza, an anchovy-tuna umami bomb on dough. WHY PS.CAFE PETIT TEAM. WHY DO YOU HATE ME.

Ok, if it&#39;s any indication of how big a fan I am, I&#39;ve been here approximately 4 times in slightly over a month ever since Josh T. introduced me to this place. (Giving credit where credit is due) <br><br>It&#39;s located near my workplace (10 minutes at a moderate walking pace) and I&#39;ve been making trips here for spontaneous dinners after work, or when I have an hour or so to burn.<br><br>I&#39;ve tried the garlic flatbread, the TRUFFLE garlic flatbread, the fennel sausage pizza, the caesar salad, the chicken rossa penne and 2 flavors of ice cream (hazelnut and some other one that I can&#39;t remember offhand).<br><br>The garlic flatbread comes in thin triangular slices, almost like a thin-crust pizza, and is very very garlicky and satisfying, though the portion is huge for one. Even with 2 we were stuffed. Best shared amongst a group of 4 (there are 8 slices). The truffle version was good but I didn&#39;t think it was worth the additional $4.<br><br>The pizza was unique and the kurobuta pork and fennel sausages complemented each other nicely. I&#39;m not a big fan of tomatoes and the tomato was strong in this one. I felt that the crust, while thin, could be less dense and doughy. Pizzeria Mozza is still my preferred place when it comes to pizzas in general, but this is a worthy competitor.<br><br>The chicken rossa penne was ok, again the tomato was strong in this one. Al dente penne is served in a tomato-cream sauce with what I thought was a pile of melted cheese on the top (but the menu mentions spinach, chicken and mushrooms). They serve their stuff in takeaway boxes, with the pasta separate from the dressing, so you have to pour in the sauce yourself. The pasta itself was nicely cooked but this dish failed to impress. <br><br>Their ice cream is $6, a tad pricey but the first time I was there, I was given two huge scoops (I smiled nicely). It was delicious, smooth and creamy with the distinct taste of hazelnut. The second time was also good but not as wonderful as the first (I suspect this is why I can&#39;t remember what I ate).<br><br>Oh and it says &#34;takeaway&#34; everywhere but there are actually enough seats for about 15 people inside. And a clean toilet.

First time here, we walked in and was greeted with the usual &#34;for 3&#34;? Was told to pick any table and order at the cashier without realizing it&#39;s a takeaway only place. Eric didn&#39;t explain either. <br><br>When order arrived, I asked for an additional box realizing they likely don&#39;t have plates so my daughter could share the food without spilling all over but Eric was reluctant to give us an additional box. <br><br>I wouldn&#39;t come back again to a place where customers are made to beg for an additional box which I doubt would be a difference in profit or loss. <br><br>Setting expectations is key and the situations could&#39;ve been dealt with much better.

I love PS cafe downtown. So when one opened in Tiong Bahru, I was very happy about it. Finally went to check it out with a Friend. Take away menu only. Okieeeeeee ... Then what&#39;s with all the nice nice places to sit and the pretty pretty deco? Anyways... <br><br>Was given a seat, given the menu, and was told to go order at the counter. Which is all well and good - a lot of cafes does that. Menu is kinda basic, don&#39;t expect a lot to choose from. And after paying, was told that I had to collect my food as well. Okieeeeee... Bear in mind the kind of prices you are paying .... <br><br>Order pizza, a salad, a cuppa coffee and a juice. When I went to collect the food, all were in paper boxes.... But ok, they did say take away only. The salad came in the box and we were suppose to share so I went to ask for another box. I was told that they don&#39;t give any more boxes.  was the expression on my face. Went to take two paper cups to use as container to share out the salad. <br><br>Not the most environmentally friendly kinda place. And for the a-bit-above-average-cafe-prices that you are paying, I think it&#39;s only right to expect a wee bit more. <br><br>That said, if you are willing to pay that price for take away only, you are in luck, because the food is decent. I liked their pizza but the whole experience really put me off. <br><br>If I wanna go back to a PS cafe, will go to the one downtown.

This is meant to be a take-out joint for pizza which explains the limited tables and chairs inside the store. Despite also being a test kitchen for PS Cafe, it is beautifully decorated with chrome, faux brick and black wood paneling. The menu is written on the chalkboard and has a wall full of wine to go along with the pizzas. <br><br>The selection is simple. Purely pizza and 1 salad option. As it is not a full fledged cafe or restaurant, they are not allowed to serve food on plates and cups etc. The pizza came in a box and drinks are in a take-away plastic or paper cups. Plastic cutlery and napkins are provided if you wish to have a quick meal on the premises. But seriously, the place is not meant dining in. If you want to eat there, it will be better to either come at non peak (read lunch or dinner hours). It is definitely a very nice place to wait for your pizza to be ready and have a drink or so while waiting. <br><br>There is a small selection of gigantic muffins for sale too. They look temptingly delicious. <br><br>The four cheese porcini was very good, just out of the oven and made with fresh ingredients. The salad with blueberries, pine nuts, wolfberries, sunflower seeds etc was equally to die for. I love the freshness of the food. I am not sure if the pizza will hold up well if you need to travel for long as the steam will usually make pizza a bit soggy after a while. <br><br>But this is a great find for fantastic pizza for those living in the Tiong Bahru area.

$40 (tax included, no service charge) for a good salad and a good pizza in Singapore is unheard of. Their ice cream is also good and the wine doesn&#39;t look overpriced.<br><br>I suppose I should eat in HDB estates more often. Their lower rents seem to enable them to charge less for good food. Need to try the other restaurants in this area which look good also.

text: Conversely from other P.S. Cafés, the service here is pretty bad. I know that there&#39;s no service charge, and it&#39;s supposed to be a quick service restaurant (I&#39;m trying to withhold using the term fast food joint here), but the utter nonchalance and bluntness of the staff here is ludicrous.<br><br>Staffers are supposed to stand aside/make way for customers when they&#39;re walking through, but not here. I live nearby and patronize the cafe relatively often, and I always observe them trying to boss their way around, forcing customers to either bump into them or give way. Needless to say I wasn&#39;t going to let them push me around, but the experiences I&#39;ve had were really unpleasant.<br><br>The positives - truffle fries here are great, and are their pizzas. But my favorite has gotta be the Pullman&#39;s panini. Juicy chunks of chicken with mustard pressed between a cheesy and crisp panini, it&#39;s one of my favorite sandwiches around.<br><br>I prefer the food here compared to the full restaurants, which tend to sometimes be over complicated, as they are simple, fast, and tasty.<br><br>Overall, quite the opposite from the main restaurants. In both a good and bad way.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=690cxERsi3FBEoBOb2MOoQ', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/ioIcQYFrO-Fiku3KNNn5vg/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/ioIcQYFrO-Fiku3KNNn5vg/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/ioIcQYFrO-Fiku3KNNn5vg/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/ioIcQYFrO-Fiku3KNNn5vg/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/ioIcQYFrO-Fiku3KNNn5vg/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/ioIcQYFrO-Fiku3KNNn5vg/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Ryan M.', 'displayLocation': 'Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Ryan M.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=690cxERsi3FBEoBOb2MOoQ', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 17, 'photoCount': None, 'reviewCount': 10, 'eliteYear': None}
text: This place was great for a late night pizza when we first arrived in Singapore. We tried many places throughout Tiong Bahru, but this was probably our favorite. The pizza is delicious and made to order. Wine and beer are reasonably priced and they have a nice selection of different types of wine and craft beers. Overall a great experience topped off with a great  caramel topped cake dessert. Yum!

We did a drive-by pick up and ordered:<br>Four Cheese Pizza - hubby ordered this and I tried a couple of bites. I&#39;m really not that impressed with pizza taste actually. The pizza come with Chilli Paste, not chili flakes. Interesting... Hubby commented it&#39;s actually nicer with the Chilli paste. That&#39;s not saying very much for the taste of the pizza. Crust is not bad, pretty thin and crusty. <br><br>Spaghetti Bolognese - daughter liked it enough but I tried a mouthful and it was only so-so. Not a dish to go there for.<br><br>Chicken Cream Pasta - I actually forgot the actual name on the menu but the taste is unforgettable!! To me, the pizza and spag bolognese are only so-so in truth and this pasta dish with chicken chunks really made the entire trip to hunt down PS. Cafe Petit.<br><br>For the records, we are SO not going back any time soon.

text: Had a simple Margarita pizza for 22, big enough for my boyfriend and I to share. I loved it!   The decor of th cafe is so new york, black subway tiles and lots of mirrors. The concept is take-away, but I loved being in there and didn&#39;t want to leave! Also had a Dai Dai ipa for 14 bottled. I will go back for the extensive wine selection and to try some other eats.

Four Cheese Porcini Pizza ($28.00)', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Four Cheese Porcini Pizza ($28.00)'}]
text: Love Petit&#39;s recent extension - it&#39;s turned it into a swanky hideaway that&#39;s fitting for a quiet casual gathering amongst friends. A glass of wine, pizzas to share and ice cream afterwards makes it the ideal venue to enjoy some of the best that the PS. brand has to offer. It&#39;s the smokey, crisp and slightly chewy crust is what makes the pizzas from PS. Petit stand out. The service can vary when they get busy, but the upside is - there&#39;s no service charge.
Really good food! The staff is so nice, too. I ate here a few times during my 2 week stay in Singapore and will eat there again when I return!

Love the interior because it transports me of to a secret hideout in New York. Food and drink wise, they are kept to pizzas and sandwiches and more tea cakes. Food that goes well with wine or coffee, get the drift? As usual, prices at ps cafe would be lovely at -20% but when there&#39;s demand, why bother?

text: Perfect after work spot to have a glass of wine from a fantastic selection while you wait for delicious takeout.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=WPw0LDmsT5HLc5itX8YLVA', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/QQtHcqWr8HF7TFfsN5BHtA/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/QQtHcqWr8HF7TFfsN5BHtA/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/QQtHcqWr8HF7TFfsN5BHtA/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/QQtHcqWr8HF7TFfsN5BHtA/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/QQtHcqWr8HF7TFfsN5BHtA/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/QQtHcqWr8HF7TFfsN5BHtA/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Joel Y.', 'displayLocation': '麻布十番駅, Minato, Japan', 'altText': 'Joel Y.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=WPw0LDmsT5HLc5itX8YLVA', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 417, 'photoCount': 141, 'reviewCount': 704, 'eliteYear': None}
text: One of the best pizza I have ever had in my life. Honestly, better than Mozza here in Singapore. Classy, friendly and great pizzas.  Absolutely perfect texture and chewiness in the crust, delectable and amazing creations and combinations.  Awesome wines to go with it- ensuring you to have an amazing &#34;high class&#34; pizza night.  Don&#39;t miss the great baked goods. This branch is the hub for all of the delectable and scrumptious pastries that are delivered throughout the island... so make sure to snatch up some amazing new and creative desserts while visiting! Bravo!

Cautious upon entering but very pleasantly surprised with the excellent quality of food, albeit in takeaway form. The pizza is the best we&#39;ve had in Singapore and the pasta was close too. Excellent service to round out the experience.

text: I am so excited PS.Cafe opened in my hood! Granted it&#39;s only a take-out place, it&#39;s great to have great pizza, and many bottles of wine available for purchase. In the usual PS.Cafe style, there are also very limited seats available should you choose to dine there.

text: With a selection of high quality artisan breads, The Dough Shoppe has also a variety of sandwiches, pastries and cakes. They have an all-day breakfast menu that is not available at their Killiney sister café, Freshly Baked. Even loved their cookies.<br><br>The place is neat and spacious, decorated with simple woody touches. There&#39;s always a staff to greet you as you step in. Although all of my purchases here were take-aways. Will definitely try dining in one day.

Soup of the day. Carrot with cauliflower. But really cauliflower with carrot', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Soup of the day. Carrot with cauliflower. But really cauliflower with carrot'}]
text: The ham and cheese sandwich was served with good quality ham (not picnic). The bread was also good quality, with a nice airy crumb and a pleasant sweetness from the fruit inside and/or some sauce it was spread with. Unfortunately the bread was a bit burnt and had a bitter edge.<br><br>The sausage baguette had good sausage which was warm, hearty and juicy. Yet, the &#34;freshly baked&#34; baguette wasn&#39;t. It wasn&#39;t fresh and was hardly crusty.<br><br>The nachos were excellent, mixing cheesy goodness (proper cheese and not American cheese) and tender flavourful pulled pork. It was very big for a side. Although it was served with thousand island dip, it was flavourful enough as is was and I found that the dip just confused the flavour profile.<br><br>Unfortunately, the service here was bad, even for Singapore.<br><br>I went to the back of the shop to see if the water was self service, saw that it was not, and then asked the female staff member for 2 cups of iced water. She then barked at me, and I quote, &#34;Go away. Not self service&#34;. I don&#39;t think any service staff in Singapore has ever been so rude to me.<br><br>The cashier also had a very sian (bored/tired) manner and spoke in a monotone when I placed my order (though she brightened up a little later).<br><br>Lastly, my nachos took more than 40 minutes to come, and I had to remind the staff once.<br><br>As such I am docking off a star from my rating of this place due to the bad service (and probably also the lack of air conditioning, which was very noticeable at lunchtime).

Went to the dough shoppe with my friends for a quick lunch. Didn&#39;t realize they have excellent brunch items on their menu. Loved the sandwiches and their soup of the day (cream of vegetable). The bread is fresh and abundant filling. Ice tea is home brewed and you get to add syrup to it, which means the sweetness is just like you want it. The sandwich soup and drink come in a combo for $10.90. I think it&#39;s a steal for the food quality and excellent and timely service.

There are an overwhelming number of food court / restaurant options on the bottom floor of the Raffles City shopping mall. They have a huge number of dessert places (cronuts, pastry shops, cookie shops) to specialty pork jerky shops to Vietnamese noodles to Hong Kong-style cafe food/dim sum to Din Tai Fung to French-style roast chicken. It&#39;s a place where everybody can find something for themselves, but seating can be limited, particularly for the cheaper food options.

Large café latte', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Large café latte'}]
text: Great plain and almond  croissants, come heated and crispy.  Also, the beef and Arugula, and the cheese, mushrooms and Arugula croissants and a good size and very filling.  Café Latte is smooth and well made.  Overall food and drink quality is high, and the revamped setting and menu is very good, it is a strong competition to Prego at the Fairmont for a quick breakfast and lunch.  They&#39;ve done away with the silly squirting fountain, and using the space for another coffee/dining place.

First a word of caution, this is not the place to come for buying food on a budget, it is a grocery store more towards to high end of the price range. With that out of the way I must say I do really love the broad selection of food from all over the world. They have an amazing range of imported foods and everything appears to be fresh and I do understand that it usually comes with a price tag attached to it so there are not really any complaints from me regarding that. <br><br>I also very much enjoy shopping here since everything is fresh, it is a pleasant atmosphere and they also have enough staff so there are people available to ask for things. In general the staff are also helpful.<br><br>They also have a nice (and by Singapore standards probably very nice) wine selection at prices that are not that bad. Some times the wines on offer actually are really good deals. I would however not really buy standard groceries such as bread, pasta, vegetables and fruit here due to the price level but for more hard to find stuff this can be the place to go.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/bsJfor1cqiihllg4gHgtuw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/raffles-city-market-place-singapore?reviewid=YYU2UWPz6CUyM-iHZU7DnQ&select=bsJfor1cqiihllg4gHgtuw', 'altText': 'Photo of Raffles City Market Place - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: I come here once in a while - when I need to grab stuff urgently, or when I need something specific. They have quite a collection of stuff - be it from spices, olives, fermented food items, milk and other basic supermarket produce. A lot of their stuff is imported, so you have quite a good selection of stuff from all over the world.<br><br>What I Love: They have quite a multitude of stuff, and it&#39;s pretty amazing. Their homemade, curries and packed sauces from the United Kingdom is somethin&#39; else. They have imported American produce too - so if you&#39;re looking for Tapioca Pudding, and other traditional American stuff - here&#39;s the place to go!<br><br>What I Don&#39;t Love: Their prices are ridiculous though. Some of their produce are like twice to three times the price compared to what you can find at other Supermarkets all over the country. That&#39;s why I go there to only buy specific stuff - not advisable to do grocery shopping on a daily basis.

Superman waffle and chicken.', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Superman waffle and chicken.'}]
text: This DC Comics superhero themed dining destination may be a tourist trap and perhaps it&#39;s the novelty of it all but, the whimsical atmosphere and creatively designed food and beverages piqued my interest. <br><br>Not only do they serve American classics, they also feature a small menu of Italian and Mexican fares. Head to the dessert section and check out the artfully crafted desserts and latte arts that would make any DC Comic fans &#34;nerd out.&#34; <br><br>Superhero decors adorn the walls and furnitures. The establishment are filled with collectibles, memorabilia, superhero murals and life-sized replica of characters. <br><br>After perusing the menu, we opted for the Batman burger and the Superman waffle and chicken. Both served with fries and salad. The food were just ok. Nothing impressive. <br><br>Their Wonder Woman vanilla latte which came with a Batman cookie was a treat! <br><br>While they are not known to serve delicious food and may not be worth the splurge as dishes sold here comes with a relatively high price tag but, the love for character themed cafes and unique dining experience will have fans trickling in.
